DIV1.P: A PLEASANT COMMODIE, CALLED Looke about you.
As it was lately played by the right honoura∣ble the Lord High Admirall his seruaunts
LONDON, Printed for William Ferbrand, and are to be solde at his shop at the signe of the Crowne neere Guild-hall gate. 1600.

DIV1.HEAD: A pleasaunt Commodye called Looke about you.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter Robert Hood a young Noble-man, a seruant with him, with ryding wandes in theyr handes, as if they had beene new lighted.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.L: GOe, walke the horses, wayte me on the hill,
This is the Hermits Cell, goe out of sight:
My busines with him must not be reueal'd,
To any mortall creature but himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Seru.
SP.L: Ile waite your honour in the crosse high-way. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Doe so: Hermit deuout and reuerend,
If drousie age keepe not thy stiffened ioyntes,
On thy vnrestfull bed, or if the houres
Of holy Orizons detayne thee not,
Come foorth.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Good morrow son, good morrow, & God blesse thee Huntington,
A brighter Gleame of true Nobility
Shines not in any youth more then in thee.
Thou shalt be rich in honour, full of speed,
Thou shalt win foes by feare, and friend, by meede.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Father, I come not now to know my fate,
Important busines vrgeth Princely Richard, Deliuer letters.
In these termes to salute thy reuerent age.
Read and be briefe, I know some cause of trust,
Made him imploy me for his messenger.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: A cause of trust indeed true honoured youth,
Princes had need in matters of import,
To make nice choyse faire Earle, if I not erre,
Thou art the Princes ward.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.P: Father I am his ward, his Chamberlaine & bed-fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Faire fall thee honourable Robert Hood,
Wend to Prince Richard, say though I am loath,
To vse my skill in Coniuration:
Yet Skinke that poysoned red cheekt Rosamond,
Shall make appearaunce at the Parlament,
He shall be there by noone assure his Grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Good morrow Father, see you faile him not,
For though the villaine did a horrible deed,
Yet hath the young King Richard, and Earle Iohn,
Sworne to defend him from his greatest foes.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Gods benizon be with thee noble Earle.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: A dew good father, holla there, my horse? Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Vp, spur the kicking Iade, while I make speede
To Consure Sknke out of his Hermits weede;
Lye there religion keep thy M. graue,
And on the faire trust of these Princes word
To Court againe Skinke: but before I goe,
Let mischiefe take aduise of villany,
Why to the Hermit letters should be sent,
To poast Skinke to the Court incontinent:
Is there no tricke in this? ha let me see?
Or doe they know already I am he?
If they doe so, faith westward then with Skinke:
But what an asse am I to be thus fond,
Heere lyes the Hermit whom I dying found
Some two monthes since, when I was howerly charg'd
With Hugh the Cryer and with Constables,
I saw him in the ready way to heauen,
I helpt him forward, t'was a holy deed;
And there he lyes some sixe foote in the ground,
Since when, and since, I kept me in his weedes.
O what a world of fooles haue fill'd my Cell;
For Fortunes, run-awaies, stolne goods; lost cattle,
Among the number, all the faction
That take the young Kings part against the olde;
Come to my selfe to harken for my selfe,
So did the aduerse party make enquire,
But eyther fall full of contrary desire:
The olde Kings part would kill me being stain'd,
The young Kings keep me from their violence.
So then thou needst not feare, goe boldly on,
Braue Hall, Prince Dicke, and my spruce hot spur John,
Heer's their safe conduct: O but for Rosamond!
A fig for Rosamond, to this hope Ile leane:
At a Queenes bidding I did kill a queane.

DIV1.STAGE: Sound Trumpets, enter with a Harrald on the one side, Henry the second Crowned, after him Lancaster, Chester, Sir Richard Faukenbridge: on the other part, K. Henry the Sonne crowned, Herrald after him: after him Prince Rich. Iohn, Leyster, being set, enters santasticall Robert of Gloster in a gowne girt: walkes vp and downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Old. K.
SP.P: Why doth not Gloster take his honoured seate?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: In faith my Liege Gloster is in a land
Where neyther suerty is to sit or stand.
I onely doe appeare as I am summoned,
And will awaite without till I am call'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Yon. K.
SP.P: Why heare you Gloster?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Henry I doe heare you.

SP.SPEAKER: Yon. K.
SP.P: And why not King?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: What's he that sits so neere you?

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: King too.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Two Kings? ha ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. K.
SP.P: Gloster sit we charge thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: I will obey your charge, I will sit downe,
But in this house, on no seate but the ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.P: The seat's too good.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: I know it brother Iohn.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Thy brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. K.
SP.P: Silence there.

SP.SPEAKER: Yon. K.
SP.P: Passe to the billes Sir Richard Faukenbridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: My Lieges both, olde Faukenbridge is proude
Of your right honour'd charge. He that worst may
Will straine his olde eyes, God send peace this day.
A bill for the releasement of the Queene prefer'd,
By Henry the young King, Rich. the Prince, John Earle
Of Murton, Bohmine Earle of Leister and the cōmons:

SP.SPEAKER: Old K.
SP.P: Did you preferre this byll?

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: We did.
Yee did not well.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Why this is good, now shall we haue the hell.
3. Bro Chester and Lanchaster you wrong the King.

SP.P: Our King we doe not.

SP.SPEAKER: Yn. K.
SP.P: Doe not you seeme crown'd?
But whilst he liues we to none else are bound.

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.L: Is it not wrong thinke you, when all the world
Troubled with rumour of a captiue Queene,
Imprisoned by her husband in a Realme,
Where her owne sonne doth weare a Diademe?
Is like an head of people mutinous.
Still murmuring at the se done her and vs?
Is't not more wrong when her mother zeale
Sounded through Europe. Affricke, Assia,
Tels in the hollow of newes thirsting eares,
Queene Elinor liues in a dungion,
For pitty and affection to sonne:
But when the true cause, Cliffords daughters death
Shall be exposed to stranger nations:
What vollumes will be writ. what lybels spred?
And in each lyne our state dishonoured.

SP.SPEAKER: Fauk.
SP.L: My Lord speakes to the purpose, mary it may bee so,
Pray God it prooue not so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.L: Heare me conclude, and there withall conclude,
It is an heynous and vnheard of sinne:
Queene Elinor daughter to Kingly Fraunce,
King Henries wife and royall Henries mother,
Is kept close prisoner for an acte of Iustice,
Committed on an odious Concubine,

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: Thou wrongst her Leister.
Leachers euer praise the cause of their confusion, she was vile
She was ill spoken of it's true, true.

SP.SPEAKER: Glosr.
SP.L: Yonder sits one would doe as much for you
Olde foole, young Richard hath a gift I know it,
And on your wife my sister would bestow it.
Heer's a good world men hate adulterous sin,
Count it a gulfe, and yet they needs will in.

SP.SPEAKER: Lei.
SP.P: What answere for the Queene?

SP.SPEAKER: Lan.
SP.P: The King replyes your words are foule slaunderous forgeryes

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: His highnes sayes not so.

SP.L: His highnes doth,
Tels you its a shame for such wilde youth,
To smother any impiety,
With shew to chastice loose adulterie.
Say Rosamond was Henries Concubine,
Had neuer King a Concubine but he?
Did Rosamond begin the fires in Fraunce?
Made she the Northerne borders reeke with flames?
Vnpeopled she the townes of Picardy?
Left she the wiues of England husbandles?
O no: she sinn'd I graunt, so doe we all,
She fell her selfe, desiring none should fall;
But Elinor whom you so much commend,
Hath been the bellowes of seditious fire,
Eyther through Iealious rage or mad desire;
Ist not a shame to thinke that she hath arm'd
Foure Sonnes right hands, against their fathers head,
And not the children of a low-priz'd wretch,
But one whom God on earth hath deified?
See where he sits with sorrow in his eyes,
Three of his Sonnes and hers tutor'd by her,
Smiles whilst he weeps, and with a proude disdaine,
Imbrace blith mirth, while his sad heart complaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Ha laugh they? nay by the rood that is not wel,
Now fie young Princes fie.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Peace doting foole.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.P: Be silent asse.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: With all my heart my Lords, my humble leaue my Lords
Gods mother asse and foole for speaking truth,
Tis terrible, but fare yee well my Lords.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Nay stay good Faukenbridge, impute it rage,
That thus abuses your right reuerend age,
My brothers are too hot.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Too hot indeed, foole, asse, for speaking truth? it's more than need.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Nay good Sir Richard at my kinde intreate
For all the loue I beare your noble house,
Let not your absence kindle further wrath,
Each side's at counsell now sit downe I pray,
Ile quite it with the kindest loue I may.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: I to his wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Prince Richard Ile sit downe,
But by the faith I owe fayre Englands Crowne,
Had you not been I would haue left the place,
My seruice merits not so much disgrace.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: Good Faukenbridge I thanke thee. Go to their places.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: And you'l thinke of him, if you can step into his bower at Stepney.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Prince Richard's very kinde, I know his kindenes,
He loues me, but he loues my Lady better,
No more, Ile watch him, Ile preuent his game,
Young Lad, it's ill to halt before the lame.

DIV1.STAGE: They breake asunder. Papers this while being offred and subscribed betweene eyther.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Ile not subscribe to this indignity,
Ile not be call'd a King but be a King;
Allow me halfe the Realme, giue me the North,
The Prouinces that lye beyond the Seas,
Wales and the Isles that compasse in the mayne.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Nay giue him all and he will scant be pleas'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: Brother you aske too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SP.L: To much, too little, hee shall haue that and more, I sweare he shall.
I will haue Nottingham and Salisbury,
Stafford and Darby, and some other Earledome,
Or by S. Iohn (whose blessed name I beare)
Ile make these places like a wildernes.
Ist not a plague, an horrible abuse,
A King, a King of England should be Father
To foure such proper youths, as Hall, and Dicke,
My brother Geffrey and my proper selfe,
And yet not giue his sonnes such maintenaunce,
As he consumes among his minions.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: Be more respectiue Iohn.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Respectiue Richard, are you turn'd pure? a changing wether-cocke?
I say it's reason Henry should be King,
Thou Prince, I Duke, as Ieffry is a Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Lan.
SP.P: What shall your Father doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: Liue at his prayers, haue a sufficient pention by the yere,
Repent his sinnes because his end is neere.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: A gratious sonne, a very gratious sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Will this content you? I that haue sat still,
Amaz'd to see my sonnes deuoyde of shame;
To heare my subiects with rebellious tongues,
Wound the kinde bosome of their Soueraigne,
Can no more beare, but from a bleeding hart
Deliuer all my loue, for all your hate:
Will this content thee cruell Elinor?
Your sauage mother, my vnciuill Queene;
The Tygresse that hath drunke the purple bloud,
Of three times twenty thousand valiant men;
Washing her red chaps, in the weeping teares,
Of widdows, virgins, nurses, sucking babes.
And lastly sorted with her damn'd consorts,
Entred alaborinth to murther loue.
Will this content you? she shall be releast,
That she may next seaze me she most enuyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Our mothers liberty is some content.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: What else would Henry haue?

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: The Kingdome.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: Peruse this byll, draw neere let vs conferre.

SP.SPEAKER: Joh.
SP.L: Hall be not answered but with Soueraignty,
For glorious is the sway of Maiesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: What would content you John?

SP.SPEAKER: Joh.
SP.P: Fiue Earledomes Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: What you sonne Richard?

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Pardon gratious father, & th'furtheraunce for my vow of penance
For I haue sworne to God and all his Saints,
These armes erected in rebellious brawles,
Against my Father and my Soueraigne,
Shall fight the battles of the Lord of hoasts,
In wrong'd Iudea and Palestina,
That shall be Richards pennance for his pride,
His bloud a satisfaction for his sinne,
His patrimony men, munition,
And meanes to waft them into Siria.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Thou shalt haue thy desire Heroyicke Sonne,
As soone as other home-bred brawles are done.

SP.SPEAKER: Lan.
SP.P: Why weepes olde Faukenbridge?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: I am almost blind, to heare sons cruell, and the fathers kinde,
Now well a neere that ere I liu'd to see,
Such patience and so much impiety.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Brother content thee this is but the first,
Worse is a brewing, and yet not the worst.

SP.P: You shall not stand to this.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: And why my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.P: The lands of Moorton doth belong to Iohn.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: What's that to me, by Acte of Parlament,
If they be mine confirm'd, he must be pleas'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.L: Be pleas'd King puppet? haue I stood for thee,
Euen in the mouth of death? open'd my armes
To sercle in seditious vgly shape?
Shooke hands with duety, bad adew to vertue,
Prophan'd all Maiesty in heauen and earth;
Writ in blacke Carracters on my white brow,
The name of rebell Iohn against his Father:
For thee, for thee, thou Otimie of honour,
Thou worme of Maiesty thou froth, thou puble.
And must I now be pleas'd in pease to stand,
While statutes make thee owner of my land?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Good pastime good, now will the theeues fall out?

SP.SPEAKER: Joh
SP.L: O if I doe, let me be neuer held
Royall King Henryes sonne pardon me father,
Pull downe this rebell that hath done thee wrong.
Dicke, come and leaue his side, assayle him Lords,
Let's haue no parly but with billes and swoordes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ki.
SP.L: Peace Iohn, lay downe thy armes, heare Henry speake,
He mindes thee no such wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: He were not best.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Why hayre-brain'd brother can yee brooke no iest?
I doe confirme you Earle of Nottingham.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: And Moorton too?

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: I and Moorton too.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Why so, now once more Ile sit downe by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Blow winde, the youngest of King Henries stocke,
Would fitly serue to make a weather-cocke.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Gape earth, challenge thine owne as Gloster lyes,
Pitty such mucke is couer'd with the skies.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Be quiet good my Lords, the Kings commaund
You should be quiet, and tis very meere,
It's most conuenient, how say you Prince Richard?

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: It is indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.L: Why that is wisely said, you are a very kinde indifferent man,
Mary a God and by my hollidame,
Were not I had a feeling in my head,
Of some suspition twixt my wife and him,
I should affect him more then all the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Take heede olde Richard, keep thee there mad lad,
My Sister's faire, and beauty may turne bad.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Robert Hood a paper in his hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.P: Roome there, make roome for young Huntington.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: A gallant youth, a proper Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Richard I haue had wrong about his wardship.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: You cannot right your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: He can and shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Not with your help but honourable youth
Haue yee perform'd the busines I enioyn'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: I haue, and Skinke is come, heere is his bill,

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: No matter for his bill let him come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Let him not enter, his infectious breath
Will poyson the assembly.

SP.SPEAKER: Gl.
SP.L: Neuer doubt, ther's more infectious breaths about your Throne,
Leyster is there, your enuious Sonnes is there;
If them you can endure, no poyson feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin
SP.P: Content thee Gloster.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: I must be content, when you that should mend all are patient,

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Welcome good Skinke thou iustly dost complaine,
Thou standst in dread of death for Rosamond,
Whom thou didst poyson at our dread commaund,
And the appointment of our gratious Mother;
See heere my Fathers hand vnto thy pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: I receiue it gratiously, wishing his soule sweet peace, in heauen for so meritorious a worke, for I feare me I haue not his heart though his hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Be sure thou hast not, murderous bloud-sucker,
To iealious enuy executioner.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Besides thou suest to haue some maintenaunce,
We haue bethought vs how wee will reward thee,
Thou shalt haue Rowden Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Glost.
SP.P: Shal he so? will you reward your murtherers with my lands

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Your lands? it is our gift and he shall haue it.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Ile giue him seasure first with this and this. Strike him.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Lay holde on Gloster.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: Holde that murtherous Skinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Villaines hands off, I am a Prince, a Peere,
And I haue borne disgrace while I can beare.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau
SP.L: Knaues leaue your rudenes, how now brother
Gloster? nay be appeas'd, be patient brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Shift for thy selfe good Skinke, ther's golde, away:
Heere will be parts.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Swonds Ile make one and stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Joh.
SP.L: I prethee be gone since thus it faileth out,
Take water, hence, away, thy life I doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: Well, farewell, get I once out of doore,
Skinke neuer will put trust in warrants more. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: Will Gloster not be bridled?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Yes my Liege and sadled too, and ryd, and spur'd, & rayn'd,
Such misery (in your Raigne) falles your friends,
Let goe my armes, you dunghyls let me speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: Wher's that knaue Skinke? I charge you see him stayd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fauk.
SP.L: The swift heel'd knaue is fled, body a me heer's rule,
Heer's worke indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Follow that Skinke, let priuy search be made,
Let not one passe except he be well knowne,
Let poastes be euery way sent speedily,
For ten miles compasse round about the Citty.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Take Gloster to you Liefetenant of the Tower,
Keep him aside till we conferre a while,
Father you must subscribe to his committing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lan.
SP.P: Why must he Henry?

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.P: Mary for this cause, he hath broke peace and violated lawes.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: So haue you all done, rebels as you be.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Good words good brother, heare me gratious Lords,

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: I prethee Faukenbridge be patient,
Gloster must of force answere this contempt.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: I will not yeeld he shall vnto the Tower,
Warden of th'Fleete take you the charge of Gloster.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Why be it so, yet stay with him a while,
Till we take order for the company
That shall attend him, and resort to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Warden of the Fleete I see I am your charge,
Be friend me thus, least by theyr commaund,
I be preuented of what I intend.

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.P: Commaund me any seruice in my power.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: I pray you call some nimble footed fellow,
To doe a message for me to my sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.L: Call in Redcap, he waiteth with a Tipstaffe, Exit one for him.
He stammers, but he's swift and trusly Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: No matter for his stammering, is this he?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: I Iam am Re Redcap s s sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Run Redcap to Stepney.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Ile be at Stepney p p presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Nay stay, goe to the Lady Faukenbridge my sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: The La La Lady Fau Fau Faukenbreech, I r r run sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: But take thy errand, tell her I am prisoner,
Committed to the Fleete.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: I am g g glad of th th that, my fa fa father the p p por∣ter sha shall ge ge get a f f fee by you. Still runnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Stand still a while, desire her to make meanes
Vnto Prince Richard for my liberty,
At thy returne (make speed) I will reward thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: I am g g gone si sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Commend me to her gentle Huntington,
Tell her in these affayres Ile stand her friend,
Her brother shall not long be prisoner:
Say I will visit her immediatlie.
Be gone sweete boy to Marian Faukenbridge,
Thou lookest like loue perswade her to be louing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: So farre as honour will I will perswade,
Ile lay loues battery to her modest eares,
Second my milde assault, you may chaunce win,
Fare parley at the least, may hap passe in. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen
SP.L: Heere take your charge, let no man speake with him,
Except our selfe, our brethren, or Earle Leicester.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Not I my Lord, may not I speake with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Yes Faukenbridge thou shalt.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: And why? he is his wiues brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Earle Iohn, although I be, I am true vnto the State, & so is he.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: What, shal I haue no seruant of my owne?

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: No but the housholde seruants of the Fleete.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: I thanke you kinsman King, your father knowes,
Gloster may boldelie giue a base slaue blowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: O but not heere, it was not well done heere.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: Farewell good Gloster, you shall heare from vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Euen what your Sonnes will suffer you to send;
Ist not a miserie to see you stand,
That some time was, the Monarch of this land,
Intreating traytors for a subiects freedome?

SP.SPEAKER: Lei.
SP.P: Let him not speake, away with him to prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Heer's like to be a well stayd common wealth,
Where in proude Leister, and licentious Iohn,
Are pillers for the King to leane vpon.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Wee'll heare your rayling Lecture in the Fleete.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: On our displeasure see he speake no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: On thy displeasure, well yee haue me heere;
O that I were within my Fort of Bungye
Whose walles are washt with the cleare streames of Aueney
Then would not Gloster passe a halfe-penny,
For all these rebels, and their poore King too.
Laughst thou King Henry? thou knows my words are true,
God help thee good olde man, adew adew.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: That Castle shal be mine, where stands it Faukenbridge

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Far from your reach sure, vnder Feckhill ridge,
Fiue hundred men (England hath few such wight)
Keeps it for Glosters vse both day and night:
But you may easily winne it, wantons words
Quickly can master men, tongues out brawle swords.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Yee are an Idyot.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: I prethee Iohn forbeare.

SP.SPEAKER: Joh.
SP.L: What shall olde winter with his frosty iestes,
Crosse flowry pleasure?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: I and nip you too, God mary mother I would tickle you
Were there no more in place but I and you.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Sease these contentions, forward to the Tower,
Release Queene Elinor, and leaue me there
Your prisoner I am sure, if yee had power,
Ther's nothing lets you but the Commons feare:
Keep your State Lords, we will by water goe,
Making the fresh Thames, salt with teares of woe.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: And wee'll by land through the Citty ride,
Making the people tremble at our pride. Exeunt with Trum∣pets two waies.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Blacke Heath quoth he, and I were King of all Kent,
I would giue it for a commodity of Apron-strings, to
Be in my cottage agen. Princes warrants, mary Skinke
Findes them as sure as an obligation seal'd with butter.
At Kings Bridge I durst not enter a boate, through
London the stones were fiery, I haue had a good
Coole way through the fieldes, and in the high way
To Ratcliffe stands a heater: Mile-end's couered with
Who goes there. Tis for me sure; O Kent, O Kent,
I would giue my part of all Christendome to feele
Thee as I see thee. If I goe forward I am stayed,
If I goe backward, ther's a roge in a red cap, he's run
From S. Iohnes after me: I were best stay heere,
Least if he come with hue and cry, he stop me yonder,
I would slip the coller for feare of the halter;
But heere comes my runner, and if he run for me,
His race dyes, he is as sure dead, as if a Parlament
Of Deuils had decreed it.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.L: Ste Ste Stepney chi church yonder, but I haue forgot
The La La Lady Fau Fau Fau plague on her,
I mu must b backe to the Fle Fle Fleete to kn kn know it.
The la the la la Lady Fau, plague on't; G Gloster
Will gone neere to st stab me, fo for forgetting
My errand, he is such a ma ma mad Lord, the
La Lady Fau Fau Fau.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Help me deuise, vpon my life this foole is sent
From Gloster to his sister Marian.

SP.SPEAKER: Redc.
SP.L: Im must nee needs goe backe, the La Lady
Fau Fau Fau.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: God speed good fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Go go god sp sp speed you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Why run'st thou from me?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Ma mary sir, I haue lo lost a La Ladyes name, and I am running ba backe to se se seeke it.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: What Lady? I prethee stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Why the la Lady Fau Fau Fau.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Faukenbridge?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: I the s s same, f f farewell, I th th thanke you ha hartily

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: If thou wouldst speake with her she is in Kent,
I serue her, what's thy busines with my Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.L: I sh sh should doe an errand to her f f from my Lord
Of Gloster, but a a and she be in k Kent, Ile s send it by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Where is my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Mary p p prisoner in the Fl Fleete, a a and w would haue her speake to P Prince R Richard for his re re re∣lease.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: I haue much busines, hold ther's thy fare by water, my Lady lyes this night.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Wh wh where I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: At Grauesend at the Angell.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Tis deuillish co co colde going by water.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Why there's my cloake and hat to keep thee warme,
Thy cap and Ierkin will serue me to ride in
By the way, thou hast winde and ty de, take Oares.
My Lady will reward thee royally.

SP.SPEAKER: Red
SP.P: G God a mercy, f fa faith and euerth thou co co come to the Fl Fl Fleete, Ile giue the tu tu turning of the ke key f for n no nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Hye thee, to morrow morning at Graues-end Ile wash thy stammering throate with a mug of ale merrily.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: God be w with you till s soo soone; what call you the Lady? O now I re remember the La Lady Fa Faukenbridge at what s signe?

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: At the Angell.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: A Angell, the la la Lady fa fa Fau kenbridge, Fa Fau Faukenbridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Farewell and bee hang'd good stammering ninny, I thinke I haue set your Redcaps heeles a running, wold your Pyanet chattering humour could as sa safely se set mee fr from the searchers walkes. Yonder comes some one, hem: Skink to your trickes this tytty tytty, a the tongue I beleeue will faile mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Come make vp to this fellow, let th'other go, he seems a gentleman, what are you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Would I had kept my owne sute, if the countenaunce carry it away.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Stand sirra, what are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: The po po Porters Sonne of the FFl Fleete, going to Stepney about businesse to the La La Lady Fa Fa Fauken∣bridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Well bring him thether, some two or three of yee ho∣nest neyghbors, and so backe to the Fleete, we'll shew our selues dilligent aboue other Officers.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Wh wh why le le let me run I am Re Redcap.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Well, sure you shall now run no faster then I lead you, heare yee neighbor Simmes, I leaue my staffe with yee, bee vigilent I pray you, search the suspitious houses at the townes end, this Skink's a trouncer; come, will you be gone sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Yes sir, and the deuill goe with you and them,
Well, yet haue hope mad ha hart, co co come your way.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: Sweet nobilitie in reuersion, Blocke by the commission of his head, Coniures you and withall bindes you, by all the tricks that pages passe in time of Parlament, as swearing to the pantable, crowning with Custords, paper whiffes to the sleepers noses, cutting of tagges, stealing of torches, cum mul∣tis aliis tell Blocke, what Blocke you haue cast in the way of my Ladies content.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.P: Block by the antiqiuity of your ancestrie, I haue giuen your Lady not so much as the least cause of dislike, if she be despleased at any newes I bring, it's more then I must blab.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: Zounds these pages be so proude, they care not for an olde Seruingman, you are a ward and so, an Earle, and no more: you disquiet our house that's the most: and I may be euen with thee that's the least.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: What Blocke, what Blocke I say what doe you there?

SP.SPEAKER: Bloc.
SP.P: Making the young Lord merry Maddame,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Go attend ye gate, see if you can let in more greife therat,

SP.SPEAKER: Blo
SP.P: Zounds and greife come in there, and I see him once Ile Coniure his gaberdine.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: will you be gone sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: Hem, these women, these women, and she bee not in loue eyther with Prince Richard or this lad, let blocks head be made a chopping blocke. Exit Blocke.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Faire Madam, what replye you to my sute,
The prince excepts smiles, welcomes, louing lookes,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: The Prince, if he giue heed to Marrians sute,
Must heare heart-sigh's, see sorrow in my eyes,
And finde cold welcome to calamities,

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: And why for gods sake?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Euen for Glosters sake,

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: why by mine honnor, and Prince Richards faith,
Your brother Gloster shall haue liberty,
Vppon condition you release a prisoner
That you haue longe held in captiuitye.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I haue no prisoner,

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.P: Yes a world of eies, your beuty in a willing bondage ties

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Go to, you are dispos'd to iest my Lord,

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: In earnest I must be an earnest suter
To you for loue, yet you must be my tuter.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Are you in loue?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: I dearely loue Prince Richard.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Then doe you loue the loueliest man aliue.
The Princeliest person of King Henries sonnes,

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: I like this well.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: he is vertuous in his minde his body faire,
His deeds are Iust, his speaches debonaire,

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Better and better still.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: In deed he is what no body can denye.
All louely, beautie all, all Maiestie.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Ile tell his excelence what you reporte,
No doubt he will be very thankfull, for't,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Nay heare you young Lord? Gods pitty staye.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: What haue you more in Richards praise to say?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I haue said to much if you misconster me.
Dutie bids praise him, not vnchastitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Vnchastitie holy heauens forfend it,
That he or I, or you should once intend it,

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: They are there sir, close at it, I leaue you sir, the more Roome the lesse company.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric
SP.P: Drinke that, farwell,

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.L: If that sir Richard comes, this ties, this bindes,
O golde, thy power conuerteth seruants mindes. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: How now faire Maddam who hath angred you?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Greife at my brothers duraunce angers me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: I had thought my Ward young Huntington had vext you

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: who he? alas good Gentleman he wrong'd me not.
No matter for all this, Ile tell your tale.

DIV1.STAGE: A noyse within, Enter Skinke, Blocke, Constable.

SP.SPEAKER: Bls.
SP.P: Sir there comes no more of you in with him then the Constable. Zounds heares a beadroll of Billes at the gate in∣deed, back ye base

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Now sirra whats the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: Marry heares a stammerer taken clipping the Kings English, and the Constable and his watch hath brought him to you to be examin'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Consta.
SP.P: No Madam wee are commaunded by the King to watch, and meeting this fellow at Mile-end, he tels vs, he is the Porters sonne of the Fleete, that the Earle of Gloster sent him to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Iff forsooth h he desire you to speake to the p Prince for him.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: O I conceaue thee, bid him blithly fare,
Beare him this Ring in token of my care.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: If I be rid of this euill Angell that haunts mee, many rings, much Fleete will Skinke come vnto.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Madam, if you know this fellow we'll discharge him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bloc.
SP.P: Madam, and you be wise, trust your honest neighbors heere, let them bring this ca ca ca ca to the Fleete, and s see your ring deliuered.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: A plague vpon you for a damned roge,
The Porter of the Fleete will surely know me.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Good neighbours bring this honest fellow thether,
Ther's for his paines a crowne if he say true,
And for your labour ther's as much for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Why Ma Ma Madam, I am Re Re Redcap the Por∣ters sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Thou hast no wrong in this, farewell good fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Best speaking to Prince Richard? no Ile try
And face out Redcap if the slaue were by.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Make them drinke Blocke.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: Come to the Buttery bar, stitty stitty stammerer, come honest Constable, hey the watch of our towne, we'll drinke trylill I saith.

DIV1.STAGE: As they goe out, enters Sir Richard Faukenbridge stealing forward, Prince and Lady talking.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Lupus in fabula my Noble Lord,
See the olde foxe Sir Richard Faukenbridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: We'll fit him well enough, second vs Robin.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Ile fit you well enough for all your hope, Fau. beckens to Blocke.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Leaue quaffing sirra, listen to their talke.

SP.SPEAKER: Bloc.
SP.P:
O while you liue beware, two are sooner seene then one: besides, beare a braine Master, if Block should be now spide, my Madam would not trust this sconce neither in
time nor tyde.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Well leaue me, now it buds; see see, they kisse.

SP.SPEAKER: Bloc.
SP.P: Adew good olde sinner, you may recouer it with a fallet of parsly, and the hearbe patience, if not sir you knowe the worst, it's but euen this.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Madam, what you desire I not deny,
But promise Glosters life and liberty,
I beg but loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: When doth she giue her almes?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Faire honourable Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Nay then they speed.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: My soule hath your deserts in good esteeme.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Witnesse these goodly times that grace my head.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: But were you the sole Monarch of the earth,
Your power were insufficient to inuade,
My neuer yeelding heart of chastity.

SP.SPEAKER: Fauk.
SP.L: Sayst thou so Mall, I promise thee for this,
Ile owe thy cherry lips an olde mans kisse;
Looke how my Cockerill droopes, tis no matter,
I like it best when women will not flatter.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: Nay but sweet Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Nay but gracious Lord, doe not so much forget your Princely worth,
As to attempt vertue to vnchastity.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: O noble youth!

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Let not the Ladyes dead griefe for her brother,
Giue life to shamelesse and detested sinne.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Sweet childe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.P: Consider that she is of high decent.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Most vertuous Earle.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Wife to the noblest Knight that euer breath'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Now blessing on thee blessed Huntington.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: And would you then first staine your Princely stocke,
Wrong beauty, vertue, honor, chastitye,
And blemmish Faukenbridges vntaynted armes?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: By adding hornes vnto our Falcones head,
Well thought on noble youth, twas well put in.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Besides my gratious Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.P: Tickle him Mall, plague him on that side for his hot desire.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: howeuer secretly great Princes sin,

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Oh now the spring she'll doe it sercretly.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: The King of all harts will haue all syns knowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.P: Ah then she yeilds not.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: Lady heer's my hand, I did but try your honorable faith

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: He did but trie her, would she haue bin tride
It had grone hard on this and on this side.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: And since I see your vertue so confirm'd,
as vice can haue no entraunce in your heart,
I vow in sight of heauen neuer againe,
To mooue like question but for loue,

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: My hart is eased, holde Blocke take vp my cloake.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: And your cap to sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: Sir Richard?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: What sweet Prince welcome yfaith,
I see youth quickly get's the starte of age;
But welcome welcome and young Huntington.
Sweet Robyn hude, honors best flowring bloome,
Welcome to Faukenbridge with all my hearte,
How cheares my loue, how fares my Marrian, ha?
Be merry chucke, and Prince Richard welcome,
Let it goe Mall I knowe thy greuances.
Away away, tut let it passe sweet girle,
Wee needs must haue his helpe about the Earle.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Let it not be delayd deere Faukenbridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Sir Richard, first make sute vnto my father,
Ile follow you to Courte and second you,

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Follow to Court, ha? then I smell a rat,
Its probable he'll haue about agayne,
Long seige makes entraunce to the strongest fort,
It must not be I must not leaue him heere,
Prince Richard, if you loue my brothers good,
Lets ride back to the Courte, Ile wayte on you,

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: He's Ielious, but I must obserue the tyme,
We'll ride vnto the Court, Ile leaue my boy
Till we returne, are you agreed to this?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Oh I hee is an honourable youth,
Vertuuos and modest, Huntingtons right heyre,
His father Gilbert was the smoothst fac't Lord
That ere bare Armes in England or in Fraunce,

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Solicitie Robin, Lady giue good eare,
And of your brothers freedome neuer feare,

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Marrian farwell, wheres Blocke? open the gate,
Come Prince God send vs to proue fortunate? Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: why doe you stay sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Madam as a Lidger to solicite for your absent loue

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Walk in the Garden I will follow you.
I faith I faith you are a noble wagge.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: An honorable wag, and wagish Earle.
Euen what you will sweet Lady I must beare,
Hoping of patience, profit will ensue.
That you will beare the Prince as I beare you.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Well said well said, Ile haue these toyes amended,
Goe, will you walke into the Garden sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: But will you promise me to bring no maides,
To set vppon my litle manship there?
You threatned whipping, and I am in feare,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Vppon my word Ile bring none but my selfe,

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: You see I am weapned, doe not I beseech you,
Ile stab them come there twenty ere they breech mee. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: This youth and Richard, think me easily wonne,
But Marrian rather will embrace,
The bony carcasse of dismaying death,
Than proue vnchast to Noble Faukenbridge,
Richard's king Henries sonne, is light,
Wanton and loues not humble modestie,
Which makes me (much contrary to my thoughts)
Flatter his humor for my brothers safetye,
But I protest Ile dwel among the dead,
Ere I pollute my sacred nuptiall bed. Exit.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Gloster in his gowne, calling

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Porter what Porter wher's this drowsie asse?

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.P: Who calles? my Lord of Gloster all alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Alone and haue your wisdomes companie,
Pray wher's the stammering chatterer your sonne?
He's euer running but he makes small haste,
Ile bring his lyther legges in better frame,
And if he serue me thus a nother time. Knocke within.
Harke sir your clients knocke, and't be your pye,
Let him vouchsafe to chatter vs some newes.
Tell him we daunce attendance in our chamber. Exit porter.
This Iohn and Henry are so full of hate,
That they will haue my head by some deuice,
Gloster hath plotted meanes for an escape,
And if it fadge, why so; if not, then well,
The way to heauen is death, this life's a hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Port.
SP.L: Why should the Watchmen come along with thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Ther's such a que question for yon s same r rogue Skink p plague keepe farre enough from him, that a an ho∣nest f fellow ca cannot w w walke the streetes.

SP.SPEAKER: Port.
SP.L: Well sir dispatch your busines with the Earle,
He's angry at your stay I tell ye that. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Sbloud what a frowne this Gloster castes at me,
I hope he meanes to lend me no more cuffes,
Such as he paide me at the Parlament.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: What mutter you, what tydings from my sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: Co commendations and s she hath s sent ye this r ring.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Hold ther's two Angels, shut the chamber doore,
You must about some busines for me strayght;
Come nearer man,

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: I feare I am to neare,

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Hast thou no tydings for my liberty?

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: No b but ye sh shall he heare f from her p p presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: And p presently sir off with your coate.
Nay quicke, vncase, I am bold to borrow it,
Ile leaue my gowne, change is no robbery.
Stutterer it's so, neare flinch, ye cannot passe,
Cry, and by heauen Ile cut thy cowards throate,
Quickly cashyre your selfe, you see me staye,

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: N n nay, b b but wh wh what m meane ye?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: To scape I hope, sir with your priuiledge,
How now, who's this, my fine familliar Skinke?
Queene Beldams minnion,

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Zounds you see ti's I.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Tyme sortes not now to know these misteries.
How thou camst by this ring, or stol'st this coate,
They are mine now in possession, for which kindenes
If I escape Ile get thee Libertie,
Or fire the fleete about the Wardens eares,
Mum budgit not a word as thou louest thy life,

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: I mum mum faire, pray God may chaunce it,
My Lord, but that my state is desperate,
Ide see your eyes out eare I would be cheated.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Walke like an Earle villaine some are comming.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Where is this Gloster?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Y y yonder he walks. Fa fa father, I let me out.

SP.SPEAKER: Port.
SP.P: Why whether must you now?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: To Ie Iericho I th thinke, tis such a h h humorous Earle.

SP.SPEAKER: Port.
SP.P: Well sir wilt please you hasten home againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: I Ile be h heare in a trice; b but p praye haue ca care of th this madcap, if he g giue vs the s s slip, s s some of vs a are like to m make a sl sl slyppery occupation on't.

DIV1.STAGE: This while John walkes and stalkes by Skinke, neuer a word betwene them.

SP.SPEAKER: Port.
SP.P: Looke to your busines sir let me alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Alone? neuer trust me if I trouble thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Mad Gloster mute, all mirth turn'd to dispaire?
Why now you see what tis to crosse a King,
Deale against Princes of the Royall blood,
Youle snarle and rayle, but now your toung is bedry'd,
Come caper hay, set all at six and seauen,
What musest thou with thought of hell or heauen?

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Of neither Iohn I muse at my disgrace,
That I am thus kept prisoner in this place.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: O sir, a number are here prisoners,
My Cousen Moorton whome I came to visite,
But he good man is at his morrow masse,
But I that neither care to say nor sing,
Come to seeke that preaching hate and prayer,
And while they mumble vp their Orisons,
We'll play a game at bowles, what saist thou Gloster?

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: I care not if I doe,

SP.SPEAKER: Joh.
SP.L: You doe not care, Let olde men care for graues, we for our sportes,
Off with your gowne, there hes my hatt and Cloake,
The bowles there quickly, hee?

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: No my gowne stirres not, it keeps sorrowe warme,
And she, and I am not to be deuorced,

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: Yes ther's an axe must part your head and you,
And with your head, sorrowe will leaue your heart.
But come shall I begin? a pound a game,

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: More pounds and we thus heauy? well begin.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.P: Rub rub rub rub.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Amen God send it short enough, and mee
A safe running with them clothes from thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.P: Play Robin, run run run.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Far enough and well, flye one foote more,
Would I were halfe so far without the doore.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.P: Now Porter whats the newes?

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.L: Your Coossen Moorton humbly craues,
Leauing your game, you would come visit him,

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Bowle Gloster Ile come presently.
So neere mad Robin? then haue after you,

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Would I were gone, make after as you may,

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Well sir tis yours, one all, throw but the Iacke
While I goe talke with Moorton: Ile not stay,
Keepe Cloake and hat in pawne Ile hould out play,

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: I would be sory Iohn but you should stay,
Vntill my bias run another way,
Now passe, and hey passe, Skink vnto your tricks,
Tis but a chaunce at hazard: there lyes Gloster,
and heare stands Skinke, now Iohn play thou thy part,
And if I scape Ile loue thee with my heart.
So porter let me foorth.

SP.SPEAKER: Po.
SP.P: God blesse your grace, ye spoke with the L. Moorton.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: I haue and must about his busines to the Courte.
It greeues me to break my sporte with Gloster,
The melancholy Earle is comfortlesse,

SP.SPEAKER: Po.
SP.L: I wold your grace would comfort him from hence,
The Fleet is weary of his company, Redcap knocks.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Drink that, some knockes, I prethee let me cut,
His head shall off ere long, neuer make doubt. Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Iohn at the other doore.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: Now madcap thou winstall; wher art thou Robyn?
Vncased: nay then he meanes to play in earnest.
But whers my Cloake, my rapier, and my hatt?
I holde my birth-right to a beggers scrip,
The basterd is escaped in my cloathes.
Tis well, he left me his to walke the streets,
Ile fire the Citty but Ile finde him out,
Perchaunce he hides himselfe to try my spleene,
Ile to his chamber, Gloster? hallo Gloster? Ex

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.L: I wonder how thou camst so strangly chang'd?
Tis not an hower since thou wents from hence,

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: By my Ch Ch Christendome I ha haue not b b been h heere this three nights, a p p plage of him, that made me such a ch chaunting, and s sent me such a Ia Ia Iaunt, blud I was st stayd for Skinke, that ill fa fa fac'd rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Port.
SP.L: I pray God there be no practise in this change.
Now I remember these are Skinkes cloathes,
That he wore last day, at the Parlament,

DIV1.STAGE: Knocke, Enter at another doore, John in Glosters gowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Porter? you Porter?

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.P: Doe you not heare them knock, you must stay sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Bloud I could eate these rogues.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.L: Wh wh what raw, tis a very hash mo morsell,
Ne next your he heart

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: A plague vpon your Iaunts, what porter slaue?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: I haue been at g grauesend sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.P: What's that to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: And at Ca Ca Canterbury.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: And at the gallows: zounds this frets my soule.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: But I c could not f finde your s s sister the La Lady Fau Faukenbridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: You stammering slaue hence, chat among your Dawes,
Come ye to mad me? while the rogue your father.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: My f fa father.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Porter? you damned slaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Port.
SP.P: Ist Midsomer doe you begin to raue?

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.L: Harke how the traytor flouts me to my teeth.
I would intreat your knaueship let me forth,
For feare I dash your branes out with the keyes,
What is become of Gloster and my garments?

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.L: Alas in your apparrell Glosters gone,
I let him out, euen now I am vndone,

SP.SPEAKER: Joh.
SP.L: It was your practise, and to keepe me backe
You sent Iacke Daw your sonne with ca ca ca,
To tell a sleueles tale: lay hould on him,
To Newgate with him and you tut atut,
Run red cap and trudge about,
Or bid your fathers portership farwell. Exeunt with Porter.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: He heares a go good Ie Ie Iest by the L Lord to mo mocke an ape withall: my fa fa father has brought his ho ho hoges to a fa fa faire m m mket. Po po porter quoth you? p po porter that will for me, and I po po porter it, let them po po post me to heauen in this qua quarter. But I must s s seeke this Gl Gl Gloster and Sk Sk Skinke that co cony catching ra ra rascall, a pa pa plauge co co confound him, Re re redcap must ru run he cannot tell whe whether. Exit

DIV1.STAGE: Sound Trumpets, Enter Henry the younger, one one hand of him Queene Elinor, on the other Leycester.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Mother and ycester adde not oyle to fire.
Wrath's kindled with a word, and cannot heare
The number lesse perswasions you infort,

SP.SPEAKER: Quce.
SP.L: O but my sonne thy father fauours him.
Richard that vile abortiue changling brat,
And Faukenbridge, are fallen at Henries feete.
They wooe for him, but intreat my sonne
Gloster may dye for this that he hath done,

SP.SPEAKER: Leic.
SP.P: If Gloster liue thou wilt be ouerthrowne,

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.P: If Gloster liue thy mother dies in moane,

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.P: If Gloster liue Leyster will flie the realme,

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.P: If Gloster liue thy kingdome's but a dreame,

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Haue I not sworne by that eternall arme
That puts iust vengance sword in Monarcks hands,
Gloster shall die for his presumption?
What needs more coniuration gratious Mother?
And honorable Leyster marke my words.
I haue a Bedrole of some threescore Lords,
Of Glosters faction,

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: Nay of Henries faction.
Of thy false fathers faction, speake the truth,
He is the head of factions; were he downe:
Peace, plenty, glory will impale thy crowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.L: I ther's the But; whose hart-white if we hit,
The game is our's. Well we may rage and roue,
At Gloster, Lancaster, Chester, Faukenbridge,
But he is the vpshot.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee
SP.P: Yet begin with Gloster.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: The destenies run to the booke of Fates,
And read in neuer-changing Characters
Robert of Glosters end he dies to day,
So fate, so heauen, so doth King Henry say.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.P: Emperially resoul'd. Trumpets far off,
The olde King comes,

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: Then comes Luxurious lust,
The King of Concubines, the King that scornes
The vndefiled, chast and numptiall bed,
The King that hath his Queene Imprisoned.
For my sake scorne him, sonne call him not father,
Giue him the stile of a competitor,

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Pride seaze vppon my heart, wrath fill myne eyes,
Sit lawfull maiestie vppon my front
Dutie flie from me, pitty bee exild,
Sences forget that I am Henries child,

SP.SPEAKER: Quee
SP.P: I kisse thee, and I blesse thee, for this thought.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: O Lancaster bid Henry yeeld some reason
Why he desires so much the death of Gloster,

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: I heare thee Henry, and I thus reply.
I doe desire the death of Basterd Gloster.
For that he spends the Treasure of the Crowne.
I doe desire the death of basterd Gloster,
For that he doth desire to pull me downe.
Or were this false (I purpose to be plaine)
He loues thee, and for that I him disdaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Therin thou shewest a hate corrupted mynde,
To him the more vniust, to me vnkynd,

SP.SPEAKER: Quee
SP.P: He loues you as his father lou'd his mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Fie, fie vpon thee hatefull Elinor.
I thought thou hadst been long since scarlet dyde,

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: She is and therfore cannot change her colour.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: You are to strickt, Earle Glosters fault Merrits not death,

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: By th'rood the Prince saies true.
Heere is a statute from the Confessor,

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: The Confessor was but a simple foole.
Away with bookes my word shall be a lawe,
England her breath shall from this bosome drawe,
Gloster shall die,

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.P: Let Gloster dye the death.

SP.SPEAKER: Lan.
SP.P: Leyster he shall not, he shall haue lawe, dispight of him and thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: What law, will you be Traitors? whats the lawe?

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: His right handes losse, and that is such a losse,
As England may lament, all Christians weepe.
That hand hath bin aduanst against the Moores,
Driuen out the Sarasins from Gads and Cicile,
Fought fifteene Battels vnder Christs red crosse,
And is it not (thinke you) a greeuious losse,
That for a slaue (and for no other harme)
It should be sundred from his Princely Arme?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: More for example Noble Lancaster, but tis great pitty,
To to great a pittie.

SP.SPEAKER: He.
SP.P: Ile haue his hand & head.

SP.SPEAKER: Ri.
SP.P: Thou shalt haue mine thē.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Wel sayd stubberne Dicke, Iack wold not serue me so,
Were the boy heere:

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Both Iohn and I haue seru'd your will too long;
Mother repent your cruelty and wrong:
Gloster you know is ful of mirth and glee,
And neuer else did your grace iniury.

SP.P: Gloster shal dye.

SP.SPEAKER: He.
SP.P: Fetch him heere Ile see him dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: He that sturs for him shall lay downe his head.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: O quiet good my Lords, patience I pray,
I thinke he comes vnsent for by my fay.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: What meanst thou Gloster?

SP.SPEAKER: He.
SP.P: Who brought Gloster hyther?

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Let Gloster hang and them that
There lyes his case, a mischiefe on his carkasse.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.P: My deare sonne Jacke?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Your deere son Iack an apes, your mōkey, your babone, your asse, your gull.

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.P: What ayles Earle Iohn?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: Hence further frō my sight,
My fiery thoughts and wrath haue worke in hand;
Le curse ye blacker then the Leuarnian Lake,
If you stand wondring at my sorrow thus;
I am with childe, big, hugely swolne with rage,
Who'll play the Midwife, and my throbs aswage?

SP.SPEAKER: Kin
SP.P: I will my Sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: I will high harted brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: You will, and you, tut, tut all you are nothing,
Twill out, twill out, my selfe my selfe can ease:
You chafe, you swell, ye are commaunding King,
My father is your footestoole when he please,
Your word's a law, these Lordes dare neuer speake,
Gloster must dye, your enemies must fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: What meanes our brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.L: He meanes that thou art mad she franticke, Leyster foolish
I the babe, these grinde vs, bite vs, vexe vs, charge,
And discharge, Gloster, O Gloster!

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.P: Where is Gloster sonne?

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Where is Glo. brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: I hope he be escaped.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: O I could teare my hayre, & falling thus vpon the
Solide earth, dig into Glosters graue, so he were dead
And gone into the depth of vnder worlds.
Or get seditiou hundreth thousand hands,
And like Briareus, battle with the Starres,
To pull him downe from heauen if he were there,

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Looke to Earle Iohn the Gentleman is mad.

SP.L: O who would not be mad at this disgrace?
Gloster the fox is fled, there lies his case,
He cousned me of myne, the porter helpt him,

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: The porter shall be hangd let's part and seeke him,
Gloster shall dye all Europe shall not saue him.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: He is wise, too wise for vs, yet Ile goe with you,
To get more fooles into my company.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.P: This is your fathers plot, reuenge it sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Father by heauen if this were your aduice,
Your head or heart shall pay the bitter price,
Come mother, Brother, Leyster, lets away,

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: I, Ile be one, in hope to meete the basterd,
And then no more my selfe will be his headsman. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Richard and Faukenbridge follow the search,
You may preuent mischaunce by meeting Gloster,
If ye finde Skinke see that you apprehend him,
I heare there is a wizard at blacke heath,
Let some enquire of him where Skinke remaynes,
Although I trust not to those fallacies,
Yet now and then such men prooue Soothsayers.
Will you be gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Withall my heart, withall my heart my Lord,
Come Princly Richard, we are ever yoak'd.
Pray God there be no mistery in this,

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: Be not suspitious where there is no cause,

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Nay nothing, nothing, I am but in iest. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: Call in a Purseuant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lan.
SP.P: Heares one my Leidge,

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: There is a Porter likely to be hangd,
For letting Gloster scape, sirra attend,
You shall haue a repreiue to bring him vs,
These boys are to to stubborne Lancaster,
But tis theyr mothers fault, if thus she moue me,
Ile haue her head though all the world reproue me. Exeuntt.

STAGE.HI: Enter Robin Hood and Lady Fankenbridge.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Doe not deny me gentle Huntington.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: My Lord will misse me.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Tut let me excuse thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Turne woman, O it is intollerable!
Except you promise me to play the Page:
Doe that, try one night, and you'l laugh for euer,
To heare the Orizons that Louers vse;
Their ceremonious sighes, their idle oathes,
To heare how you are prais'd and pray'd vnto.
For you are Richards Saint, they talke of Mary
The blessed Virgin, but vpon his beades
He onely prayes to Marian Faukenbridge.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: The more his error, but will you agree
To be the Lady Faukenbridge one day?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: When ist?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: On Munday.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Wherefore ist?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Nay then you doe me wrong with inquisition.
And yet I care not greatly if I tell thee.
Thou seest my husband full of iealousie;
Prince Richard in his sute importunate,
My brother Gloster threatned by young Henry;
To cleare these doubtes, I will in some disguise,
Goe to blacke Heath vnto the holy Hermit,
Whose wisedome in fore-telling things to come,
Will let me see the issue of my cares.
If destinyes ordaine me happines,
Ile chase these mistes of sorrow from my heart,
With the bright Sunne of mirth: if fate agree,
It, and my frends, must suffer misery,
Yet Ile be merry too, till mischeefe come.
onely I long to knowe the worst of ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Ile once put on a scarlet countenaunce.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Be wary least ye be discouered Robyn.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Best paint me then, be sure I shall not blush.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Block bleeding, Gloster with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.L: Beate an Officer, Red cap Ile haue ye talkt withall,
Beate Sir Richards Porter? help Madam, help,

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Peace you damned rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Brother I pray you forbeare.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Zwonds a hundreth at my heales almost,
And yet the villaine stands on complaiment.

SP.SPEAKER: Bloc.
SP.P: Abots one you, ist you?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Will you to the doore you foole? and bar the gate,
Holde ther's an angell for your broaken pate;
If any knocke let them not in in haste.

SP.SPEAKER: Bloc.
SP.P: Well Ile doe as I see cause, blood thou art deare to me, but heere's a soueraigne plaister for the sore: golde hea∣leth wounds, golde easeth heartes: what can a man haue more? Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Deare brother, tell vs how you made escape?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: You see I am heare, but if you would knowe how:
I cannot scape and tell the manner too,
By this I knowe your howse is compassed
With hel-hound search.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Brother Ile furnish you with beard & hayre, and Garments like my husband, how like you that? Exit. Lady

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Well, when I haue them: quickly then dispatchs blood turne gray beard and hayre?
Robyn conceale, this dyeteth my minde,
Myrth is the obiect of my humorous spleane,
Thou high commaunding furie! further deuice,
Iests are conceated, I long to see their birth,
What come ye sister? Robyn a theeues hand,
But prethee where hadst thou this beard and haire?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Prince Richard wore them hether in a maske,

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Saist thou me so, faith loue the Princely youth,
Tut you must tast stolne pleasure now and than,

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: But if she steale and Ielious eyes espie:
She will be sure condemnd of Burglary,

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Ha crake? can your low stumps venter so deep
Into affections streame? go to you wanton.
What want we now? my nightcap, O tis heare,
So now no Gloster, but olde Faukenbridge,
Harke, the search knockes, ile let them in my selfe;
Welcome good fellowe; ha, what ist you lacke?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Ma master Co constable, se se search you th that way, a and you ho honest man th that way. Ile ru run th this way m my owne se selfe. They dispearse themselues.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: What search you for? what is it you would haue?

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: Madam, what shall I doe to these browne-bill fel∣lowes? some runne into the wine seller, some heere, some there.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Let them alone, let them search their filles.

SP.SPEAKER: Block.
SP.P: Ile looke to their fingers for all that.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Doe so good Blocke, be carefull honest Blocke.

SP.SPEAKER: B.
SP.P: Sir stammerer & your wa watch, y'are pa past ifaith. Exit

SP.SPEAKER: Gl.
SP.P: Will you not speake knaues, tel me who you seeke?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Ma mary sit we s seeke a va va vacabond, a fu fugatiue, my La Ladies owne b brother; but and hee were the po po Popes owne b brother, I would ssearch f f for him; for I haue a p poore fatherr ready to be ha ha hang'd f f for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: O tis for Gloster! mary search a gods name,
Seeke peace, will he breake prison too?
It's pitty he should liue, nay I defye him.
Come looke about, search euery little corner,
My selfe will lead the way, pray you come,
Seeke, seeke, and spare not, though it be labour lost:
He comes not vnder my roofe, heare ye wife,
He comes not hyther, take it for a warning.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: You sp sp speake like an honest ge ge Gentleman, re re rest you me me mery, co co come my f f friends, I be beleeue h h he r ran by the g g garden w wall toward the wa water side. Exeunt running.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: This fellow is of the humour I would chuse my wife,
Few words and many paces, a word and a way, and so
Must I: Sister adieu, pray you for me, Ile do the like for you.
Robin farewell, commend me to the Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Can ye not stay heere safe?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: No, Ile not trust the changing humours of olde Faukenbridge,
Adieu yong Earle, Sister lets kisse and part;
Tush, neere mourne, I haue a merry hart. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Farewell all comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: What weeping Lady?
Then I perceiue you haue forgot Blacke-heath.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: No, there Ile learne both of his life and death.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.P: Till Munday Madam I must take my leaue.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: You will not misse then:

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Nay, if Robin faile yee, let him haue neuer fauour of faire Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Meane while Ile spend my time in prayers & teares,
That Gloster may escape these threatned feares. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Thus iets my noble Skinke along the streetes,
To whom each bonnet vailes, and all knees bend;
And yet my noble humour is too light,
By the sixe shillings▪ heere are two crackt groates
To helter skelter, at some vawting house.
But who comes yonder? ha, olde Faukenbridge?
Hath a braue-chaine, were Iohn and he good friends,
That chaine were mine, and should vnto Black-heath
Ile venture, it's but tryal, lucke may fall.
Good morrow good sir Richard Faukenbridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Good morrow my sweet Prince, harty good morrow,
This greeting wel becomes vs, marry does it;
Better iwis then strife and Iangling.
Now can I loue ye, wil ye to the Shiriffes?
Your brother Richard hath beene there this houre.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Yes I am plodding forward as you doe;
What cost your chaine? it's passing strongly wrought,
I would my Golde-smith had a patterne of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Tis at your graces seruice, shew it him.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Then dare ye trust me?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Who the Princely Iohn?
My Soueraignes sonne, why what a question's that?
Ile leaue you, yee may know I dare trust you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski
SP.P: Ile bring't ye to the Shiriffes, excuse my absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: I wil my noble Lord, adieu sweet Prince. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Why so, this breakfast was wel fed vpon,
When Skinkes deuises on Blacke heath doo faile,
This and such cheates, would set me vnder saile.
Ile to the water side, would it were later,
For stil I am afraide to meete Prince Iohn.
But what a mischiefe meant Faukenbridge
To come againe so soone? that way he went,
And now comes peaking; vpon my life
The buzzard hath me in suspitition,
But whatsoeuer chaunce, Ile filch a share.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Yonder's Prince Iohn I hope he cannot know me,
Ther's naught but Gloster Gloster in their mouthes;
I am halfe strangled with the Garlicke breath,
Of rascals that exclaimes as I passe by,
Gloster is fled, once taken he must dye.
But Ile to Iohn, how does my gratious Lord?
What tattles rumour now? what newes of Gloster?

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: What newes could I heare since you left me last?
Were you not heere euen now? lent me your chaine,
I thinke you dote.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Sweet Prince, age, age forgets, my brothers chaine? a pretty accident,
Ile haue't and be but in the spight of Iohn▪

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Ther's more, and more, Ile geld it eare it go. He breaks the chaine.
This same shal keep me in some sauerne merry,
Til nights blacke hand curtaine this to cleare sky.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: My sweet Prince, I haue some cause to vse my chaine,
Another time (when ere your Lordship please)
Tis at your seruice, ô mary God it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Heere palsie, take your chaine, stoop and be hang'd,
Yet the fish nibled, when she might not swallow;
Gout I haue curtall'd what I could not borrow. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: He's gone away in frets, would he might meete
My brother Faukenbridge in this mad moode,
There would be rare adoe; Why this fits me,
My braine flowes with fresh wit and pollicy.
But Gloster looke about, who haue we yonder?
Another Iohn Prince, Richard and the Shiriffe?
Vpon my life, the slaue that had the chaine,
Was Skinke, escapt the Fleete by some mad sleight,
Wel, farewel he, better and better still,
These seeke forme, yet I wil haue my will.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: Shiriffe, in any case be diligent.
Whose yonder, Faukenbridge?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: How now sweet chucke, how fares my louely Prince?

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: What carest thou? or wel, or ill, we craue no help of thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Gods mother doe you scorne me?

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Gout, what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Fye, leaue these idle braules, I prethee Iohn
Lets follow that we are inioyn'd vnto.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: I mary Prince, if now you slip the time,
Gloster wil slip away; tut though he hate me
I haue done seruice, I haue found him out.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: A shame confound thee for thy treachery,
Inconstant dotard, tymerous olde asse,
That shakes with cowardise not with yeares.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Goe, I haue found him, I haue winded him.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: O let me hug thee gentle Faukenbridge,
Forgiue my oft ill vsing of thine age,
Ile call thee Father, ile be penitent,
Bring me where Gloster is Ile be thy slaue,
All that is mine, thou in reward shalt haue.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Soft, not too hasty, I would not be seene in't,
Mary a god my wife would chide me dead,
If Gloster by my meanes should loose his head.
Princely Richard at this corner make your stand:
And for I know you loue my sister well,
Know I am Gloster and not Faukenbridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: Heauen prosper thee sweet Prince in thy escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Shiriffe, make this your quarter, make good guard.
Iohn, stay you heere, this way he meanes to turne,
By Thomas I lacke a swoord, body a me.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: What wouldst thou with a swoord olde Faukenbridge?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: O sir to make shew in his defence,
For I haue left him yonder at a house
A friends of mine, an honest Cittizen.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Wee'll fetch him thence.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Nay then you iniure me, stay till he come; he's in a russet cloake
And must attend me like a Seruingman.

SP.SPEAKER: Io
SP.L: Holde ther's my swoord, and with my swoord my heart,
Bring him for Godsake, and for thy desert,
My brother King and mother Queene shall loue thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Marke me good Prince, yonder away we come,
I goe afore and Gloster followes me;
Let not the Shiriffe nor Richard meddle with vs,
Begin you first, seaze Gloster and arrest him;
Ile draw and lay about me heere and heere,
Be heedfull that your watchmen hurt me not,

SP.SPEAKER: Io
SP.L: Ile hang him that doth hurt thee, prethee away,
I loue thee, but thou kilst me with delay.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Wel keep close watch, ile bring him presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Away then quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: Gl.
SP.P: Gloster, close master Shiriffe, Prince Richard,

SP.SPEAKER: Ri.
SP.P: Gloste radieu.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: I trust you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: By my Knight-hood Ile prooue true. Exit Gloster.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.L: Reuenge, Ile build a Temple to your name;
And the first offring shal be Glosters head,
Thy Alters shal be sprinkled with the bloud,
Whose wanton current his mad humour fed;
He was a rymer and a Ridler,
A scoffer at my mother, prays'd my father,
Ile fit him now foral, escape and all.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: Take heede spight burst not in his proper gall.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: How now, what way tooke Faukenbridge I wonder?
That is not Gloster sure that attends on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau
SP.L: He came not at the Shiriffes by the morrow masse,
I sought the Goldsmithes rowe and found him not;
Sirra, y'are sure he sent not home my chaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: Who should send your chaine sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: The Prince, Prince Iohn I lent it him to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: What's this they talke?

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: By my truth Sir, and ye lent it him, I thinke you may goe look it: for one of the Drawers of the Salutation tolde me euen now, that he had tooke vp a chamber there till e∣uening, and then he will away to Kent.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Body of me, he meanes to spend my chaine,
Come Blocke Ile to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Iob.
SP.P: Heare you Faukenbridge?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Why what a knaue art thou? younders Prince Iohn.

SP.SPEAKER: Bl.
SP.P: Then the Drawer's a knaue, he told me Prince Iohn was at the Salutation.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Wheres Gloster Faukenbridge?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Sweet Prince I knowe not.

SP.SPEAKER: Joh.
SP.P: Come, iest not with me, tell me where he is?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau
SP.P: I neuer saw him since the Parlament.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Impudent lyar, didst thou not euen now
Say thou woldst fetch him? hadst thou not my sword?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Wert thou a King, I will not beare the lye,
Thy sword? no boy, thou seest this sword is myne.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: My Master a lyer? Zounds wert thou a potentate,

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: I scorne to weare thy armes vntutred childe,
I fetch thee Gloster? shamelesse did I see thee
Since as I went this morning to the Siriffes,
Thou borrowedst my gold chaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Thy chaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: I hope thou wilt not cheate me princkocks Iohn.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Ile cheat thee of thy life if thou charge me
With any chaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Come, let him come I pray, Ile whip yee boy, Ile teach you to out face.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: Come, come, come, but one at once, ye dasterds come

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Keepe the Kings peace, I see you are both deceau'd,
He that was last heare, was not Faukenbridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: They slaunder me, who sayes that I was heare?

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Wee doe beleeue ye sir; nor doe you thinke
My brother Iohn deceiu'd you of a chayne.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: He did, I did deliuer it with this hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Joh.
SP.P: Ile dye vpon the slanderer,

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Let the boy come.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: I, let him come, let him come.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Fellow, thou spakst euen now, as if prince Iohn
Had byn at some olde Tauerne in the towne.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.L: I sir, I came vp now, but from the Salutation,
And a drawer that doth not vse to lye, tolde me
Prince Iohn hath byn there all this after noone.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.P: The Deuill in my likenesse then is there.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: The Deuill in thy likenesse or thy selfe,
Had my gold chaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.L: Thou art the Deuill, for thou
Hadst my good sword, all these can witnesse it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Gods Mother thou bely'st mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Giue me the lye?

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Nay calme this fury, lets downe to the Tauerne,
Or one, or both, these counterfeites are there.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: I know him well enough that had my chaine,
And there be two Iohns, if I finde one there,
Ber Lady, I will lay him fast.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: It is this Skinke that mockes vs I beleeue.

SP.SPEAKER: Joh.
SP.L: Alas poore Skink it is the Deuill Gloster;
Who if I be so happy once to finde,
Ile giue contentment, to his troubled minde.

SP.SPEAKER: Rcih.
SP.L: I hope he's far enough, and free enough:
Yet these conseytes I know delight his soule.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Followe me Blocke, follow me honest Blocke.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: Much follow you, I haue another peece of worke in hand; I heare say Redcaps father shall bee hanged this after noone, Ile see him slip a string though I giue my seruice the slip; beside my Lady bad me heare his examination at his death: Ile get a good place, and pen it word for word, and as I like it, set out a moornefull Dittie to the tune of Laban∣dalashot, or rowe wel ye Marriners, or somwhat as my muse shall me inuoke. Exit.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Gloster like Faukenbridge with a Purseuant, Gloster hauing a paper in his hand, the Purseuant bare.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: A charytable deed, God blesse the King,
He shall be then repreeued.

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.P:
I sir, some day or two, till the young King and Prince
Iohn chaunge it, especially if the good Earle bee not found which God forbid.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: What house is this that wee are stept into to read this warrant in?

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.P: A Tauerne sir, the Salutation,

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: A Tauerne? then I will turne prodigall,
Call for a pint of Sacke good fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.P: Drawer?

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: Anan sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: A pint of thy best Sacke my pretty youth.

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: God blesse your worship sir, ye shal haue the best in London sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gl.
SP.L: What knowst thou me? knowst thou old Faukenbridge?
I am no Tauerne hunter I can tell thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: But my Master hath taken many a faire pound of your man Blocke; he was heere to day sir, and fild two bot∣tles of nippitate sacke.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Well, fill vs of your nippitate sir.
This is well chaunest, but heere ye boy?
Bring Suger in white paper, not in browne;
For in white paper I haue heere a tricke,
Shall make the Purseuant first swound, then sicke.
Thou honest fellow what's thy name?

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.P: My name is Winterborne sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: What countryman I prethee?

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.P: Barkeshire and please ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Gl.
SP.P: How long hast thou bin sworne a messenger?

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.L: But yesterday and please your worship,
This is the First imployment I haue had.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Drawer with wine and Suger.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: A good beginning, heere haue too thee fellow;
Thou art my fellow now thou seruest the King,
Nay take Suger too, Gods Lady deere,
I put it in my pocket, but it's heere:
Drinke a good draught I prethee Winterborne.

DIV1.STAGE: He drinkes and falles ouer the stoole.

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: O Lord Sir Richard, the man, the man.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: What a forgetfull beast am I? peace boy,
It is his fashion euer when he drinkes.
Fellow he hath the falling sickenes,
Run fetch two cushions to rayse vp his head,
And bring a little Key to ope his teeth. Exit Drawer.
Purseuant, your warrant and your boxe,
These must with me, the shape of Faukenbridge
Will holde no longer water heere about.
Gloster wil be a proteus euery houre,
That Elinor and Leyster, Henry, Iohn,
And all that rabble of hate louing curres,
May minister me more mirth to play vpon.

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: Heer's a key sir, and one of our folke to help.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: No matter for a key, help him but in,
And lay him by the fire a little while,
He'll wake immediatly, but be hart sicke,
Ther's money for a candle and thy wine,
Ile goe but vp vnto your Aldermans,
And come downe presently to comfort him. Exeunt

SP.SPEAKER: Within Ski.
SP.P: Drawer? what Drawer? with a vengeance Dra.

SP.SPEAKER: Within Dra,
SP.P: Speake in the Crowne there.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: They be come, the deuill crowne yee one by one,
Skinke tho' art betraide, that master Faukenbridge
Missing some of his chaine, hath got thee dog'd.
Drawer? what Drawer?

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: Anan, anan sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: Was not sir Richard Faukenbridge below?

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: Yes and please yee.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: It does not please me wel, knowes he that I am heer?

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: No I protest.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: Come hether sirra, I haue little money,
But ther's some few linkes of a chayne of golde:
Vpon your honesty knowes not sir Richard,
That I am heere?

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: No by my holydam.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Who's that was with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: Why a Purseuant.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
