SP.P: Where is sir Richard?

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: At the Aldermans.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: A Purseuant and at the Aldermans.
What Pyg, or Goose, or Capon haue you kill'd,
Withing your Kitchin new?

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: A pyg new stickt.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Fetch me a sawcer of the bloud, quicke run; Exit.
Ile sit the Purseuant, and Alderman,
And Faukenbridge, if Skinke haue any wit.
Well Gloster, I did neuer loue thee yet,
But th'art the maddest Lord that ere I met,
If I scape this, and meete thee once againe,
Cursse Skinke, if he dye penny in thy det.

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: O my Lord the house is full of holberts, and a great many Gentlemen aske for the roome where Prince Iohn is?

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Lend me thy Aprone, runne and fetch a pot from the next roome.
Betray'd, swounds betray'd, by gout, by palsie, by dropsie;
O braue boy, excellent bloud: vp, take my cloake
And my hat to thy share, when I come from Kent, ile pay
Thee like a King.

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: I thanke you my Lord. Exit.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter John, Richard. Faukenbridge, Shiriffes and Officers.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: Now fortune help or neuer: they come, and yee were a Prince as yee say ye are, yee would bee ashamed to abuse a poore seruant thus, but and if you were not of the bloud Royall, Ide breake the necke of yee downe the stayres, so would I, Ide teach you to hurt prentises.

SP.SPEAKER: Ri.
SP.P: Who hurt thee fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Prince deuill or his dam, Prince Iohn they call him.

SP.SPEAKER: Joh.
SP.P: Gloster I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Ri.
SP.P: I doubt not but it's Skinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Where is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Vp them stayres, take heede of him.
He's in the Crowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Alas poore fellow, he hath crown'd thee shrewdly.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: In recompence, if it be him I seeke,
Ile giue thee his whole head to tread vpon.
Follow me brother, come olde Faukenbridge,
Keep the stayres Shiriffes, you see it waxeth darke,
Take heede he slip not by you. Exeunt

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: Hange your selues, this darkenes shal conuay me out, of doors
Ile swim the Thames, but Ile attaine Black-heath,
London farewell, curse Iohn, raue Faukenbridge,
Skinke scapes you all by twy lights priuyledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Within.
SP.P: Where is he? lights, bring lights, drag out that boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: This is my cloke, my hat, my rapier,
And eyther it was Skinke or Gloster.

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: I know not who twas sir, he said he was Prince Iohn, he tooke away my aprone and a pottle pot with him, and al to bloudied his head and face.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: We met him, by S. Anthony, we met him.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: The fire of S. Anthony confound
This changing counterfeit whatsoeuer he be.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: It makes me laugh at enuious greedines,
Who feedes vpon her owne harts bitternes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.L: Sirra you that were borne to cry anan,
What other copesmates haue you in the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Sir, my Maisters gesse be none of my copesmates,

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Well your gesse, can ye gesse who they be?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: Marry heere's a purseuant, that this Gentleman sir
Richard Faukenbridge left sick euen now.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Marry of God dyd I, thou lying knaue?

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: I am a poore boy sir, your worship may say your plea∣sure, our maides haue had a foule hand with him, you said he would be sicke: so he is with a witnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.L: Looke about Faukenbridge, heere's worke for you,
You haue some euill Angell in your shape,
Goe sirra, bring vs foorth that Purseuant?

DIV1.STAGE: Enter two leading the Purseuant sicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Gloster, thou wilt be too too venterous,
Thou doost delight in those odde humours so,
That much I feare they'll be thy ouerthrowe. aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.P: O O O not too fast; O I am sicke, O very sicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: What picture of the pestilence is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Purs.
SP.P: A poore man sir, a poore man sir: downe I pray yee, I pray let me sit downe. A sir Richard, sir Richard, a good sir Richard: what haue I deseru'd to be thus dealt with all at your worships hands? a ha, ah, ah.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: At my hands knaue? at my hands paltry knaue?

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: And I should be brought to my booke oath sir:

SP.SPEAKER: Within.
SP.P: What Ieffrey?

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: Anan, anan.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.P: A plague vpon your Ieffring, is your name Ieffrey?

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: I and't please you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Why gentle Ieffrey then stay you awhile,
What can you say, if you come to your booke?

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: If I bee pos'd vpon a booke sir, though I bee a poore prentise, I must speake the truth, & nothing but the truth sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: And what's your truth sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.P: O, O my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: Mary sir this Knight, this man of worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Well, what of me? what did my worship doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: Mary ye came into the Bel, our roome next the Barre, with this honest man as I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: As thou tak'st it?

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.P: O sir tis too true, too true, too true O Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.L: And there he call'd for a pint of Sacke, as good Sacke
(Ile bee pos'd vpon all the bookes that euer opened and shut) as any is in all Christendome.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Body of me, I come and call for Sacke?

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.P: O ye did, ye did, ye did, O O.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.P: Well forward sirra.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: Gloster hath done this iest.

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: And you call'd then for Suger sir, as good Suger and as wholsome, as euer came in any cup of Sacke: you drunke to this man, and you doe well God be thanked, but hee no sooner drunke:

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.P: But I, but I, but I, O my head, O my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: I cannot chuse but smile at these conseites.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: I am mad, and yet I must laugh at Faukenbridge:
Brother, looke how sir Richard actes his rage?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: I came? I call? the man is like to dye,
Practise by th'emafse, practise by the marry God,
Iohn loues me not, Prince Richard loues my wife,
I shall be charg'd heere, for a poysned knaue.
Practise by th'Lord, practise I see it cleare.

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.P: And more Sir Richard, O Lord O Sir Richard,

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.P: What more? what hast thou more? what practise more?

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.L: O my box, my box, with the Kings armes, O my box,
O my box, it cost me, O Lord euery penny O, my box,

SP.SPEAKER: Rcih.
SP.P: And what of your box sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: Mary sir it's lost, & tis wel knowne my Master keeps no theeues in his house, O there was none but you and he.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: O then belike thou thinkest I had his box,

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.P: O sir Richard I will not, O Lord I will not charge you for all the world, but, but, but for the warrant the olde King signd to repreeue the Porter of the fleet, O God, O God!

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.P: The Porter of the Fleet, the olde king signd,

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.P: I my good Lord, oh, oh,

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Is he repreiued then?

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.P: No my Lord, O sir Richard tooke it from me with his owne hand, O.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Heeres a deuice to bring me in contempt
With the olde King, that I euer lou'd,
Princes and Shiriffe, you can witnesse with me,
That I haue bin with you, this after noone,
Onely with you, with no body but you,
And now a fellow whome the King would saue,
By a repreiue, this fellow sayes is hang'd,

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: If thou hadst done it, Ide haue iustified it,
But Richard I conceipt this iest already,
This mad mate Skinke, this honest merry knaue,
Meeting this Purseuant, and hearing tell
He had a warrant to repreeue a slaue,
Whome we would hang: stole it away from him.
This is sure the Iest, vpon my life it is,

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.P: O but my warrant, how shall I doe? O,

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: But looke about you, hot braind brother Iohn,
And I beleeue you'l finde it otherwise,
Gloster hath got the warrant in disguise,
And sau'd the fellow you so faine would hang.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: No, no, how say you M. Shiriffe, is he not hang'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Shi.
SP.L: My Lord, the gibbet was set vp by noone
In the olde Bayly, and I charg'd my men,
If I returne not, though it were by Toarch light,
To see him executed ere they come.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: I am greedy to heare newes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Rob'd of my chaine, out-fac'd I had a swoord,
Accus'd of poysoning, cousonage, seeking bloud?
Not to be borne: it is vntollerable.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: Sir Richard, I prethee haue some patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Ile to Blacke-heath, talke not of patience,
It is intollerable, not to be borne.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: It is intollerable not to be borne,
A warrant brother, Faukenbridge a warrant?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: I saw no warrant, I defie you all.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: A slaue, a Purseuant, one winter borne.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: I care not for thee that winter borne.

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.P: O it is I sir, that's my warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Ist you? you rogue, you drunkerd; yeare cheated,
And we are cheated of the prisoner,
Out dog, dog.

SP.SPEAKER: Pur.
SP.P: O ô ô ô my Lord. Exit and Drawer.

SP.SPEAKER: Shi.
SP.P: Haue patience and we wil haue a priuy search.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.L: Goe hang ye block-heads, get ye from my sight,
O would I were a Basiliske, to kill
These gleare ey'd villaines.

SP.SPEAKER: Shir.
SP.L: Come away let's leaue him, Exeunt Shiriffes and Officers.
We haue a warrant let him doe his worst.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Ile to Blacke-heath, Ile to the holy Hermit,
There shall I knowe not onely these deceiuers,
But how my wife playes fast and loose with Richard.
Ha, I shall fit them, Ile tickle them,
Ile doo't, Ile hence, Ile to the Heath amaine, Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.L: There shall I know, where this damned Gloster is,
Ile haue the Deuils rous'd to finde that Deuill,
Or else Ile coniure the olde Coniurer.
Ile to Blacke-heath, and there with friends conspire,
But Ile haue Glosters head my hearts desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Would mad Earle Robyn saw these humouristes.
Twol'd feed him fat with Laughter; O twold sit him,
Where euer he is, I knowe the bate consaite
Is better to him than his daintiest foode,
Well, and it fits mee well, now I haue time,
To coort my Lady Faukenbridge at leysure,
Loue I emplore thy aide faire Cipria,
Thou sea-borne mother at affections ring,
Shine brightly in thy sphere, that at my starre,
My plannet thou of all lights most beautious,
Be thou to my desires Auspitious. Exit.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Robin Hood in the Lady Faukenbridges gowne, night attire on his head.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: O for this Lady, was neuer poore Gentleman troubled with Gentlewoman as I am with my selfe, my Lady Fauken∣bridge hath fitted me a turne, heere I am visited with sleeue∣lesse errands and with asking for this thing Madam and that thing Madam, that they make me almost mad in earnest, whoop heer's another Client.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Heer's my Lady Rawfords Page attends to speake with your Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: I pray ye bid her Lordships Page come into my
Ladyship: well Robin Hood, part with these pettycoates,
And cast these loose deuices from thy backe,
Ile nere goe more vntrust, neuer bee kercheft.
Neuer haue this adoe, with what doe you lacke?

SP.SPEAKER: Pag.
SP.L: Madam my Lady greets your honour kindely,
And sends you the first grapes of her young vine.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob
SP.P: I am much indepted to her honour, thers an angel for you to drinke; set them vp till after supper. Humphery, pray looke about for Blocke. Humphery? trust mee I thinke the foole be lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: No forsooth, Madam hee's vpon the greene Iesting with a stammerer, one Redcap.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: It is a lewd fellowe, pray bid him come in youth, Ile giue him his welcome at the doore: commend me to your Lady, I pray ye hartily. Exit Page

Humphrey, I maruell where sir Richard is so late? truely, truely hee does not as beseemes a gentleman of his calling, pray let some goe foorth to meete him on the greene, and send in that blockehead Blocke. Exit Humphrey.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Redcap and Blocke after him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bloc.
SP.P: Wil ye tel tales ye asse, will ye?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Ile te te tell your La La Lady or I would to g God we were ha hang'd else, as my fa father should haue bin.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Now what's the matter there I pray you? what com∣pany haue you there a gods name? where spend you the day I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Bloc.
SP.P: Why where you gaue me leaue, at the gallows I was, no farther.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: A a and you be his La Lady, you are the La Lady Fau Faukenbridge, the Earle of glo Glosters sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: I am so fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Y y your man b b Blocke heere, does no nothing but f f floute m me, a and cr cries r run Re Redcap ad s s see your f f father ha ha hang'd. I sh shal g go neere to m make m mur∣der and he v vse it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Wel firra, leaue your mocking you were best, Ile bob your beetle head and if you mocke him.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: He's run Redcap.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: La la law ma Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Away ye saucy foole, goe waite within.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: Run Redcap, run Redcap. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Art thou the Porters sonne, that was condemned a∣bout my brother Gloster?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: I g g God be with ye, I am the p p Porters son, I m must r run to s s seeke your b br brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Wel, drinke that fellow, if thou finde my brother bee not too violent, and Ile reward thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: I th th thanke ye h hartily, and I had not bin cousoned with Sk Skinke, I had no nee need of these ia iaunts, for Gl Gloster was s safe enough.

STAGE.HI: Enter Blocke and the Porter with his cloake muffled.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: Ah farewel Redcap.

SP.SPEAKER: Red,
SP.P: Fa fare we wel and be ha hang. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: You'll neuer leaue your knauery, whose there more?

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: One Madam that hath commendations to you from your brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Commest thou from Gloster? thou art welcome friend

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: O it's one of the kindest Ladies (though she wil now & then haue about with Block) that euer breath'd and she had been in her mood now, Redcap would haue made her such sp sp sport as't a pa pa past.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Wil you make sport and see who knockes againe?

SP.SPEAKER: Bl.
SP.P: Our gates are like an Anuile, from foure to ten, nothing but knicke a knocke vpon't. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Wil you be gone sir? honest friend I am glad
My brother Gloster got thy liberty,
Whose flight was cause of thy captiuity:
Nor shal there be in vs such negligence,
Though thou haue lost thy Office and thy house,
But we wil see thee better farre prouided,
Than when thou wert porter in the Fleete.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.L: Madam your olde friend Prince Richard,
All alone, making mone, fetching many a greeuous grone.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Prince Richard come so late? lights to his chamber,
Sirra, in any case say I am sicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: Very sicke, sicke and like to dye: Ile sing it and you wil.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: Away ye knaue, tel him, in the morning
Ile humbly waite vpon his excellence.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: That's all his desire to haue ye lowly and humble, and tis a courteous thing in a Lady. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: Hence, or else ile set you hence: goe in good friend.
Come Lady Faukenbridge, it's time to come,
Robin can holde out no longer I see,
Hot wooers will be tempters presently. Exit

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: Now holy Skinke in thy religious weed,
Looke out for purchase, or thy wonted clyants:
Warrents quoth you, I was fairely warrented,
Young Robin Hood the Earle of Huntington,
Shall neuer fetch me more vnto his Prince.
SP.STAGE: Enter Ladie Faukenbridge in Merchants wiues attyre.
SP.L: But pauca verba Skinke, a prize, a prize,
By th'mas a pretty girle, close Hermit close,
Ore-heare if thou canst, what she desires,
For so my cunning and my credit spreads.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: See how affection armes my feeble strength,
To this so desperate iourneying all alone,
While Robin Hood young Earle of Huntington,
Playes Lady Faukenbridge for me at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: What mistery is this? the Lady Faukenbridge,
It's she, sweet fortune thou hast sent her wel,
I will intice this morcell to my Cell:
Her husband's iealious, I will giue him cause,
As he beleeues, I hope it shall succeed;
Nay swounds it shal, she's mine in scorne of speed.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: By this broad beaten path, it should appeare,
The holy Hermits Caue cannot be farre,
And if I erre not, this is he himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: What honour'd tongue enquereth for the Hermit?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: What honour'd tongue?

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: I Lady Faukenbridge,
I know ye, and I know for what you come.
For Gloster and your husbands iealousie.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: O thou, whose eye of contemplation,
Lookes through the windows of the highest heauens,
Resolue thy Hand-maide, where Earle Gloster liues:
And whether he shal liue, and scape the hate,
Of proude young Henry and his brother Iohn?

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: Ile haue you first in, Ile tel you more anone.
Madam, they say bushes haue eares and eyes,
And these are matters of great secrecy:
And you'll vouchsafe enter my holy Cell,
There what you long to know, ile quickely tell.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Stay heere are strangers.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: A plague vpon them, come they in the nicke,
To hinder Raynald of his Foxes tricke?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Good day olde Hermit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: So to you faire Dame.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: By Elinors gray eye she's faire indeed;
Sweet heart come ye for holy benizons?
Hermit hast thou good custome with such Cliants?
I cannot blame your feates, your iugling trickes,
Plague iuggle you.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Why cursse ye sacred worth?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Ill done in sooth my Lord, very ill done,
Wrong holines: a very pretty woman.
Mocke grauity; by the masse a cherry lippe,
A it's not wel done, deride a holy Hermit?

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.P: I haue it in my purse shall make amends.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: His purse and yours, shall make me some amends,
For hindring me this morning from the Lady;
For scaring me at Tauerne yesternight,
For hauing backe your chaine, Ile fit you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Hermit, a word.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: A word with you faire mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Where lye your deuils that tel all your newes?
Would you would trouble them for halfe an houre,
To know what's become of traytor Gloster,
That in my cloathes brake prison in the Fleete?

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: No, it was Skinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Come olde foole yee dote.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: But heare me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Heare him Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Swounds who heares you? Ile make your Lady graft ye for this worke: but to your tale sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: Knowe thrise honour'd Prince, that Skinke did cousen
Redcap of his cloathes.
Gloster did couzen Skinke, and so escapt.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Well done Faukenbridge?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: My Lord, he tels you true.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: You finde it on her lippes: but forward sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: Twas Skinke in Glosters gowne, whome you did visit,
That playd at bowles and after stole your cloths,
While you went into the Lord Moortons chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: This sauors of some truth,

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Tis very like,

SP.SPEAKER: Joh.
SP.P: Well Faukenbridge by heauen Ile tell your wife,

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: She'l much beleeue you: you will come?
Tell me of my wife: this euening faile me not.
My wife quoth you: Ile send my wife from home,
Do, tell my wife prince Iohn, by my deare mother,
I loue her too too well to like another.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: It seemes so fox, O what a world is this,
There most sinne raynes where least suspition is,

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: You'l come.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I will not faile, I warrant you,

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Hermit is all this true,

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: Himselfe deliuer not so much before ye sleepe,
Roote me from out the borders of this Realme.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: Well by your leaue sir Richard Faukenbridge,
Hence free from feare, you'l melt you'l melt olde man,

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Nay take her to you, she is a shrow I warrant,
Ile to the holy Hermit, and inquire,
About my chaine your sword, the Purseuant
And other matters that I haue to aske.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: Your welcome good sir Richard,

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Nay doe not stand on tearmes, I am fire, all life,
Nor neuer tell me that I haue a wife.
I doe not meane to marry, ye think so,
But to be merry, you the manner knowe.
And you will haue me, haue me, poynt a meeting,
Ile be your true loue, you shall be my sweeting,
If you deny to promise, this is plaine
Ile haue my will eare you get home againe.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: most gratious Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Tut tell not me of grace I like no goodnes but a beautious face.
Be therefore breefe, giue me your hand & sweare,
Or Ile away with you into the heath,
Neither shall Faukenbridge nor Hermit helpe,
And what I doe Ile answer well enough.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Why, then my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: Nay do not stand on then,
But tell me when my Lord shall haue you Lady,
Its presently, ile venter for a baby.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: This night at stepney by my summer house,
There is a tauerne which I sometime vse,
When we from London come a gossoping,
It is the Hinde,

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Giue me thy pretty hand.
Thou'lt meet me at the Hinde, Ile by thy Roe,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: One word's enough,

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.P: Suffice then be it so,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Ile fit my olde adulterer and your grace,
Ile send the Princesse thether in my place.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.L: Prince Iohn, Prince Iohn the Hermit teles me wonders.
He sayes it was Skinke that scapt vs at the Tauerne,
Sk nke had my chaine: nay sure that Skinke did all.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: I say goe but to yonder corner,
And ere the Sun be halfe an hower higher,
Ther will the theefe attempt a robery,

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Who Skinke?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Will Skinke?

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: I Skinke vpon my word.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Shal we goe seaze vpon him good Prince Iohn?

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Nay we will haue him that's no question.
And yet not hurte the honest rogue.
he'll helpe vs well in quest of changeing Gloster,
Hermit farwell, Lady keepe your houre.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Adeiu olde Hermit: soone in th'euening Lasse,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Ile meet you both, and meet with both of you.
Father what answere doe you giue to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: Lady start downe I must into my cell,
Where I am curing of a man late hurt,
He drest, I must vnto my Orizons,
In halfe an houre al wil be dispatcht,
And then I will attend your Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: At your best leasure father, O the life
That this thrise reuerend Hermit leadeth heere.
How farre remote from mortall vanities,
Baites to the soule, enticements to the eye?
How farre is he vnlike my lustfull Lord?
Who being giuen himselfe to be vnchaste,
Thinke all men like himselfe, in their effects,
And iniures me, that neuer had a thought,
To wrong the sacred rytes of spotlesse faith.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Skinke with a patch on his face, and a Faulconers lure in his hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: Hermit farewel, ile pay ye or speake with ye next time I see yee. Sweete mouse the Hermit bids you stay heere, he'll visit you anon. Now Iohn and Faukenbridge, Ile match yee, and I doe not say Skinke's a wretch, a wren, a worme, when I haue trickt them, Madam I will trimme you. Com∣modity is to be prefer'd before pleasure. About profit Skink, for crownes for crownes, that make the kingly thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I am assur'd that man's some murderer, Exit.
Good Father Hermit speake and comfort me,
Are ye at prayers good olde man? I pray ye speake,
What's heere a beard? a counterfeited hayre?
The Hermits portes? garments and his beades?
Iesus defend me I will fly this denne,
It's some theeues caue, no haunt for holy men.
What if the murderer, (as I ges him one)
Set on my husband, tush Prince Iohn and hee
Are able to defend them noble selues,
How eare, I will not tarry, Ile away,
Least vnto theft and rape, I prooue apray. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Younder they are Ile fit them, heer's my ground:
Wa ha how, wa ha how, wa ha how?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: I warrant ye my Lord some man's distrest.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.P: Why man tis a Faulconer.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.P: Mary of me good fellow, I did think thou hadst bin robd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: Rob'd, sir no, he that comes to rob me shal haue a hard match on't, yet two good fellows had like to bin rob'd by one tall theefe, had not I stept in: abots on him, I lost a hauke by him, & yet I car'd not to send another after him, so I could find the theefe; and here about he is. I know he is squatted.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Sayst thou me so? we'l finde him by S. Mary.
An honest fellow, a good common wealths man.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: There are caues heereabout good fellow, are there not?

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: Yes sir, tread the ground sir, & you shal heare their hollownes, this way sir this way.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Help Faukenbridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: O help me good prince Iohn.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Ile helpe you both, deliuer sir deliuer, Swounds lin∣ger not: Prince Iohn put vp your pursse, or ile throw pon∣niards downe vpon your pate. Quickely, when? I am Skink that scapt ye yesternight, and fled the Fleete in your cloake, carrying mee cleane out of winde and raine. I broke the bonds and linkes that fettered your chaine amity, this cheate is mine: Farewel I cannot stay, sweet Prince, olde Knight, I thanke ye for this pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Gods mary mother, heer's a iest indeed,
We came to take, a theefe takes vs:
Where are ye good my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: No matter where, I thinke I was fore-spoken at ye teate,
This damn'd rogue seru'd me thus? Gloster and he
Vpon my life conclude in villany.
He was not wont to plot these stratagems,
Lend me your hand a little, come away,
Let's to the Cell againe, perchaunce the Hermit
Is Skinke, and theefe, and Hermit al in one.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Mary a God then ten to one its so,
Wel thought on Princely Iohn,
He had my chayne, no doubt he had your swoord.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.L: If there be now no Hermit at the Cel,
Ile sweare by al the Saints its none but he. Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Gloster in the Hermits gowne, putting on the beard.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: This accident hath hit thy humour Gloster,
From purseuant ile turne a Hermit now.
Sure he that keeps this Cell is a counterfeit,
Else what does he heere with false hayre and beard?
Well how so eare it be, Ile seeme to be
The holy Hermit: for such fame there is,
Of one accounted reuerend on this heath.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: Ile faine vnto my cell, to my faire Lady,
But Iohn and Faukenbridge are at my heeles.
And some od mate is got into my gowne,
And walks deuoutly like my counterfeite,
I cannot stay to question with you now,
I haue another gowne, and all things fit,
These guests once rid, new mate? Ile bum, Ile marke you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gl.
SP.L: What's he a gods name? he is quickly gone,
I am for him, were he Robin-good fellow,
Whose yonder the Prince Iohn and Faukenbridge?
I thinke they haunt me like my genii,
One good the other ill, by th'mas they prye
And looke vppon me but suspitiously.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: This is not Skinke, the Hermit is not Skinke:
He is a learned reuerend holy man.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: He is he is a very godly man.
I warrant ye, he's at his booke at's prayers,
Wee should haue tooke you, by my hollydam
Euen for a very theefe.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Now God forfend such noblemen as you should gesse me so,
I neuer gaue such cause for ought I knowe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.L: Yet thou didst tell vs Skinke should doe a roberye,
Appoynted vs the place, and there we found him,

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: And he felt vs, for he hath rob'd vs both.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: He's a lewd fellow, but he shall be taken.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: I had rather heere of Gloster then of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo
SP.L: Gloster did cheat him, of the same golde chaine,
That deceiu'd Sir Richard Faukenbridge.
He got your sword Prince Iohn: twa's he that saude
The porter, and beguil'd the Purseuant,

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.P: A vengaunce on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Doo not cursse good Prince, he's bad enough, twere better pray for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: Ile kill thee, and thou bid me pray for him.
Ile fell woods, and ring thee round with fire,
Make thee an offring vnto fierce reuenge,
If thou haue but a thought to pray for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: I am bound to pray for all men, chefely christians.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.L: Ha ha, for christians, thinkst thou he is one?
For men: hast thou opinion he is a man?
He that changes himselfe to sundry shapes,
Is he a christian? can he be a man?
O, Irreligious thoughts,

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Why worthy Prince I saw him christened, dept into the font

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Then nyne times like the northen laplanders,
He backward circled the sacred Font,
And nyne times backward sayd his Orisons,
As often curst the glorious hoast of heauen,
As many times inuocke the fiends of hell,
And so turn'd witch, for Gloster is a witch.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Haue patient Gentle Prince, he shall appeare,
Before your Kingly father speedily.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Shall he indeed? sweet comfort kisse thy cheeke,
Peace circle in thy aged honoured head,
When he is taken: Hermit I protest
Ile build thee vp a chappell and a shrine:
Ile haue thee worshipt, as a man deuine,
Assure he shall come, and Skinke shall come.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: I that same Skinke, I prethee send that Skinke,

SP.SPEAKER: Joh.
SP.L: Send both, and both as prisoners crimminate
Shall forfeite their last liues to Englands state,
Which way will Faukenbridge?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Ouer the water, and so with al speed I may to Stepney

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: I must to Stepney too, and reuile, and be blith,
Olde winke at my mirth, t'may make amends,
So thou, and I, and our friends, may be friends,

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Withall my heart, withall my heart Prince,
Olde Faukenbridge will waite vppon your grace,
Be good to Gloster for my Marrians sake,
And me and myne you shall your seruants make,

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Of that anon my pleasure being seru'd,
Gloster shall haue what Gloster hath deseru'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Why, that's well said, adew good honest Hermit, Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Hermit farwell, if I had my desire,
Ile make the world thy wonderous deeds admire, Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Still good, still passing good, Gloster is still
Henryes true hate, foe to Iohns froward will.
No more of that for them in better tyme,
If this same Hermit be an honest man,
He will protect me by this simple life,
If not I care not, Ile be euer Gloster,
Make him my foot stole if he be a slaue,
For Basenesse ouer worth can haue no power.
Robin be thinke thee, thou art come from Kings.
Then scorne to be slaue to vnderlings,
Looke well about thee Lad and thou shalt see,
Them burst in enuy that would iniure thee.
Hermit Ile meet you in your Hermits gowne,
Honest, Ile loue you: worse, Ile knocke you downe. Exit.
Kinde friends, wee haue troubled Lady Faukenbridge,
And eyther she's not willing to be seene,
Or els not well: or with our boldnesse greeu'd,
To ease these I haue brought you to this window,
Knowing your are in musicke excellent,
I haue pend a ditty heere: and I desire
You would sing it for her loue and my content,

SP.SPEAKER: Musi.
SP.P: With all my heart my Lord.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Robin Hood like the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Your excellence forgets your Princely worth,
If I may humbly craue it at your hands,
Let me desire this musicke be dismist.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: For beare I pray and with draw your selues.
Be not offended gratious Marrian, Exeunt Musicke.
Vnder the vpper heauen, nine goodly spheres,
Turne with a motion euer musicall,
In Pallaces of Kings, meliodious sound
Offer pleasures to ther soueraignes eares.
In Temples, milke white clothed queristors,
Sing sacred Anthemes bowing to the shrine,
And in the feelds whole quires of winged clarkes,
Salutes the morning bright and Christaline,
Then blame not me, you are my heauen, my Queene,
My saint, my comfort, brighter then the morne,
To you all musicke, and all praise is due.
For your delight you for delight was borne,
The world wold haue no mirth, no ioy, no day,
If from the world your beautie were away.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Fie on loues blasphemie and forgery,
To call that in, thats onely misery,
I that am wedded to suspitious age,
Solicited by your lasciuious youth,
I that haue one poore comforte liuing,
Gloster my brother, my hie harted brother,
He flies for feare, least he should faint and fall
Into the hands of hate tirannicall.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: What would you I should doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: I would full faine, my brother Gloster had his peace againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Shall loue be my reward if I doe bring
A certaine token of his good estate.
And after pacyfie my brothers wrath?
Say you'l loue, we'l be fortunate,

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: No more, I vow to dye vnblest
If I performe not this inposed quest,
But one word Madam pray can you tell,
Where Huntington my ward is?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: I was bold to send yong Robin Hood your noble ward
Vpon some busines of import for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ri.
SP.L: I am glad he is imployde in your affayres,
Farewell kinde faire, let one cloudy frowne
Shaddow the bright sunne of thy beauties light.
Be confident in this, ile finde thy brother,
Rayse power but we'l haue peace, onely performe
Your gratious promise at my backe returne.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Wel, heer's my hand, Prince Richard that same night
Which secondeth the day of your returne,
Ile be your bedfellow, and from that houre
Forsweare the loathed bed of Faukenbridge:
Be speedy therefore, as you hope to speed.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: O that I were as large wing'd as the winde,
Then should you see my expeditious will:
My most desire, adew, guesse by my haste,
Of your sweet promise the delicious taste. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Why so: I am rid of him by this deuise,
He would else haue tyred me with his sighes and songs,
But now I shall haue ease, heere comes the Saint,
To whom such sute was made.

SP.SPEAKER: Bl.
SP.P: My Lady Gentlewoman is euen heere in her priuitye walke, Madam heer's the Marchants wife was heere yester∣day would speake with yee; O I was somewhat bolde to bring her in.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.P: Wel leaue vs sir; y'are welcome gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.L: These women haue no liberality in the world in them,
I neuer let in man to my Lady, but I am rewarded.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Please ye to walke sir? wherfore mumble ye?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Robin what newes? how hast thou done this night?

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: My Ladiship hath done my part, my taske,
Lyne all alone for lacke of company,
I might haue had Prince Richard,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Was he heere?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: He went away but now; I haue bin lou'd & wood too simply,
God rid me of the woman once againe,
Ile not be tempted so for all the world,
Come, wil you to your chamber and vncase?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Nay keep my habit yet a little while,
Olde Faukenbridge is almost at the gate,
I met him at Black heath iust at the Hermits,
And taking me to be a Merchants wife,
Fell mightily in loue, gaue me his ring,
Made me protest that I would meete him heere.
I tolde him of his Lady, O tut quoth he,
Ile shake her vp, ile packe her out of sight,
He comes kinde Robin Hood, holde vp the iest.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Sir Rich. Faukenbridge and Blocke.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Gods mary knaue, how long hath she bin heere?

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: Sir she came but euen in afore you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.L: A cunning queane, a very cunning queane,
Go to your busines Block, ile meete with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: Ah old Muttonmounger I beleeue heer's worke towards. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Doe not beleeue her Mall, doe not beleeue her:
I onely spake a word or two in iest,
But would not for the world haue bin so mad,
Doe not beleeue her Mall, doe not beleeue her:

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: What should I not beleeue? what doe you meane?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Why good Sir Richard, let me speake with you,
Alas wil you vndoe me? wil you shame me?
Is this your promise? came I heere for this?
To be a laughing stocke vnto your Lady

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: How now Sir Richard, what's the matter there?

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.L: Ile talke with you anon, come hyther woman?
Didst not tel my wife what match we made:?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I tel your wife? thinke ye I am such a beast?
Now God forgiue ye, I am quite vndone.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Peace duck, peace ducke, I warrant al is wel.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: What's the matter? I pray ye sir Richard tell me?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Mary Mall thus, about some twelue monthes since,
Your brother Gloster, that mad prodigall,
Caus'd me to passe my word vnto her husband,
For some two thousand pound: or more perchaunce,
No matter what it is, you shall not know,
Nay ye shal neuer aske to know.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: And what of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Mary the man's decayde,
And I beleeue a little thing would please her;
A very little thing, a thing of nothing.
Goe in good Mall, and leaue vs two alone,
Ile deale with ye as simply as I can.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Fox looke about ye, ye are caught yfaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Deale with her simply, ô ho; what kinde of dealing?
Can ye not deale with her and I be by?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Mary a God, what are ye iealous?
Ye teach me what to doe: in, get you in.
O I haue heard Prince Richard was your guest,
How dealt you than? In get you in I say,
Must I take care about your brothers debts,
And you stand crossing me, in, or ile send you in. Exit Robin.
Ha sirra, you'l be master, you'l weare the yellow,
You'l be an ouer-seer: mary shal yee.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Ye are too curst (me thinkes sir) to your Lady;

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Ah wench content thee, I must beare her hard,
Else she'l be prining into my dalliances:
I am an olde man sweet girle I must be merry,
All steele, al spright, keep in health by change,
Men may be wanton, wowen must not range.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: You haue giuen good counsel sir, ile repent me,
Heer's your ring, ile onely loue my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: I meane not so, I thinke to day thou toldes me
Thy husband was an vnthrift, and a bankrout,
And he be so, tut thou hast fauour store,
Let the knaue beg, beauty cannot be poore.

SP.SPEAKER: La
SP.L: Indeed my husband is a bankrout,
Of faith, of loue, of shame, of chastity,
Dotes vpon other women more then me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Ha doe he so? then giue him tit for tat,
Haue one so young and faire, and loues another,
He's worthy to be coockolded by the masse.
What is he olde or young?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: About your age.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.L: An old knaue and cannot be content with such a peate,
Come to my closet girle, make much of me,
We'll appoint a meeting place some twise a weake,
And ile maintaine thee like a Lady, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: O but you'll forget me presently,
When you looke well vpon your Ladies beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Who vpon her? why she is a very dowdy,
A dishclout, a foule Iipsie vnto thee,
Come to my closset lasse, there take thy earnest
Of loue, of pleasure and good maintenaunce.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I am very fearefull.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Come foole neuer feare I am Lord heate, who shall disturb as then?
Nay come, or by the rood Ile make you come,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Help Madam Faukenbridge for gods sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: How now, what meanst?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Help Gentle Madam help,

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: How now what aylst thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Bloc.
SP.P: Nay and't be a woman, nere feare my master Madam

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Why speakst thou not, what aylst thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Why nothing, by the rood nothing she ayls.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: O Madam this vile man would haue abused me,
And forcst me to his closset,

SP.SPEAKER: Rob,
SP.P: Ah olde cole, now looke about, you are catcht,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Call in your fellowes blocke,

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.P: Doe not thou knaue,

SP.SPEAKER: La,
SP.P: Doe or Ile cracke your crowne,

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: Nay Ile doo't, I knowe she meanes to shame you. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Why Mall wilt thou beleeue this paultrie woman?
Huswife Ile haue you whipt for slaundring me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: What Leacher, no she is an honest woman,
Her husband's well knowne, all the houshold knowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: Heer's some now, to tell all the towne your mynd,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Before ye all I must sure complaine,
You see this wicked man, and ye all knowe
How oft he hath byn Iealous of my life,
Suspecting falshood being false himselfe;

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: O maister, O maister,

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: She slaunders me, she is a cousoning queane,
Fetch me the Constable, Ile haue her punisht,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: The Constable for me fie, fie vpon ye.
Madam do you know this ring?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: It is sir Richards.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: O I, that's my masters too sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: I mary, I did lend it to the false drab
To fetch some money for that bankrout knaue
Her husband, that lyes prisoner in the Fleete.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: My husband bankrout? my husband in the Fleete prisoner?
No, no, he is as good a man as you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: I that he is, and can spend pound for pound
With thee yfaith, wert richer then thou art,
I know the gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Nay Madam he is hard by, there must be Reuelles at the Hinde to night;
Your copesmate there, Prince Iohn.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Ther's a hot youth.

SP.SPEAKER: Bl.
SP.P: O, afierce Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: He was fierce as you, but I haue matcht him,
The Princesse shall be there in my attyre.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: A plaguy crafty queane, mary a God
I see Prince Iohn, coorted as well as I,
And since he shal be mockt as well as I,
Its some contentment.

SP.SPEAKER: Bl.
SP.L: Masse he droopes, fellow Humphrey, he is almost taken,
Looke about ye old Richard?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Hence knaues, get in a little, prethee Mall
Let thou and I and she, shut vp this matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Away sirs, get in.

SP.SPEAKER: Bl.
SP.P: Come, come let's goe, he wil be baited now, farewel old Richard. Exit

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Now sir, what say you now?

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.L: Mary sweet Mall I say I met this woman, likt her, lou'd her,
For she is worthy loue I promise thee;
I say I coorted her: tut make no braule
Twixt thou and I, we'l haue amends for all.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.P: Had I done such a tricke, what then? what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Ah prethee Mall, tut beare with men.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: I, we must beare with you; you'l be excus'd,
When women vndeserued are abus'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Nay doe not weep, pardon me gentle Lady,
I know thee vertuous, and I doo protest,
Neuer to haue an euill thought of thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: I, I, ye sweare, who's that that will beleeue ye?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Now by my holy dam and honest faith,
This Gentlewoman shall witnes what I swea e.
Sweet Ducke a little help me?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Trust him Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: I will be kinde, credulous, constant euer,
Doe what thou wilt, ile be suspitious neuer.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.P: For which I thanke noble Faukenbridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Body of me who's this? yong Huntington?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: And I your Lady whome you coorted last,
Ye lookt about you ill, foxe we haue caught ye,
I met ye at Blacke heath, and ye were hot.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: I knew thee Mall, now by my swoord I knew thee,
I winkt at all, I laught at euery iest.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: I, he did winke, the blinde man had an eye.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.P: Peace Robin, thou't once be a man as I.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Well, I must beare it all.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.P: Come, & ye beare, its but your office, come forget sweet Mall.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I doe forgiue it and forget it sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.L: Why that's well said, that's done like a good girle:
Ha sirra, ha you matcht me pretty Earle?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: I haue, ye see sir I must vnto Blacke heath,
In quest of Richard, whom I sent to seeke
Earle Gloster out, I know he's at the Hermits;
Lend me your Coach; Ile shift me as I ride,
Farewell sir Richard. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Farewell Englands pride, by the mattins Mall it is a pretty childe;
Shall we goe meete Iohn? shall we goe mocke the Prince?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: We will.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.L: O then we shall haue sport anon,
Neuer weare yellow Mall, twas but a tricke,
Olde Faukenbridge wil stil be a mad Dicke. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Doe ye s s say fa fa father Hermit, th that Gl Gloster is about this Heath?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: He is vpon this Heath Sonne looke about it,
Run but the compasse, thou shalt finde him out,

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: R r run? ile r run the co compasse of all k Kent but Ile f finde him out, my f f father (where ere hee layes his head) dare ne neuer co come home I know, t t till hee bee fo fo found.

SP.SPEAKER: Gl.
SP.P: Wel thou shalt find him, knowst thou who's a hunting?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: M m mary tis the Earles of La La Lancaster and Le Leyster. Fa fa farewell f father, and I finde Skink or Glo Glo∣ster, Ile g g giue thee the pr prise of a penny p p pudding for thy p paines.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Adew good friend: this is sure the fellow
I sent on message from the Parlament.
The Porters sonne, he's still in quest of me,
And Skinke that cousoned him of his red cap.
SP.STAGE: Enter Richard like a Seruing man.
SP.L: But looke about thee Gloster, who comes yonder?
O a plaine seruingman, & yet perhaps his bags are lyn'd,
And my pursse now growes thin: if he haue any I must share with him.
And who's on yond side? O it is my Hermit,
Hath got his other sute since I went foorth.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: Sbloud yonder's company, ile backe againe,
Else I would be with you counterfeite,
Ile leaue the rogue till opportunity,
But neuer eate till I haue quit my wrong. Exit

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: I saw two men attend like holy Hermits,
One's slipt away, the other at his beades,
Now Richard for the loue of Marian,
Make thy inquiry where mad Gloster liues.
If England or the verge of Scotland holde him,
Ile seeke him thus disguis'd: if he be past
To any forraigne part; ile follow him.
Loue thou art Lord of hearts, thy lawes are sweet,
In euery troubled way, thou guidst our feete.
Louers inioyn'd to passe the daungerous Sea
Of big swolne sorrow, in the Barke affection;
The windes and waues of woe need neuer feare,
While Loue, the helme doth like a Pylate steare.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Heer's some louer come, a mischiefe on him,
I know not how to answere these mad fooles,
But ile be briefe, ile marre the Hermits tale;
Off gowne, holde Buckler, slice it bilbowe blade.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: What's this? what should this meane? old man, good friend

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Young foole deliuer else see your end.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: I thought thou hadst been holy and a Hermit.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: What ere you thought, your pursse? come quickly sir?
Cast that vpon the ground, and then conferre.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: There it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Falles it so heauy? then my heart is light.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Thou't haue a heauy heart before thou touch it,
Theft shrinde in holy weedes? stand to't y'are best.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: And if I doe not, seeing such a pray,
Let this be to me a disaster day.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: Art thou content to breath? Fight & part once or twise

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: With al my heart, take halfe thy money & we'l friendly part.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: I will not cherish theft.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Then I defye thee. Fight againe and breath,

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Alas for pitty, that so stout a man,
So reuerend in aspect, should take this course.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: This is no common man with whom I fight,
And if he be, he is of wondrours spright,
Shall we part stakes?

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: Fellow take the pursse vpon condition thou wilt follow me▪

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: What waite on you? weare a turn'd Liuery?
Whose man's your master? If I be your man,
My mans mans office will be excellent:
There lyes your pursse againe, win it and weare it. Fight.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Robin Hood, they breath, offer againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Clashing of weapons at my welcome hyther?
Bickring vpon Blacke-heath, well said olde man,
Ile take thy side, the yonger hath the oddes.
Stay, end your quarrell, or I promise ye
Ile take the olde mans part.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: You were not wont yong Huntington, stil on Richards side

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Pardon gratious Prince I knew ye not.

SP.SPEAKER: Gl.
SP.L: Prince Richard: then lye enuy at his foote,
Pardon thy cousen Gloster, valiant Lord,
I knew no common force confronted myne,
O heauen I had the like conseite of thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: I tell thee Robin Gloster thou art met,
Bringing such comfort vnto Richards heart.
As in the foyle of warre when dust and sweat,
The thirst of weake, and the Sunnes fiery heate,
Haue seazd vppon the soule of valiaunce,
And he must faint except he be refresht.
To me thou comst as if to him should come,
A perry from the North, whose frostie breath
Might fan him coolnesse in that doubt of death.
With me then meets, as he a spring might meet,
Cooling the earth vnder his toyle partcht feet,
Whose christall moysture in his Helmit taine,
Comforts his spyrits, makes him strong againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Prince, in short termes if you haue brought me comfort
Know if I had my pardon in this hand
That smit base Skinke in open Parlament,
I would not come to Court, till the high feast
Of your proud brothers birth day be expyred,
For as the oe King as he made a vow
At his vnluckie Coronation,
Must waite vpon the boy and fill his cuppe,
And all the Pieres must kneele while Henry kneeles
Vnto his cradle; he shall hang me vp,
Eare I commit that vile Idolatrie.
But when the feast is past if you'll befrend me,
Ile come and braue my proud foes to their teeth,

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Come Robin, and if my brothers grace denye,
Ile take thy parte, them and their threates defye,

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Gramercy Princly Dicke,

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: I haue some power, I can rayse two thousand Soldiers in an hower,

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Gramercy Robin, gramercy little wag,
Prince Richard, pray let Huntington
Carry my sister Faukenbridge this ring,

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Ile carry it my selfe, but I had rather
Had thy kinde company, thou mightst haue mou'd
Thy Sister, whome I long haue vainely lou'd,

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: I like her that she shunes temptation
Prince Richard, but I beare with doting louers,
I should not take it well, that you vrge me
To such an office: but I beare with you,
Loue's blind and mad, hie to her boldly, try her;
But if I know she yeeld, faith Ile defie her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: I like thy honorable resolution,
Gloster I pray thee pardon my intreate,

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: its mens custome; part part Gentle Prince,
Farwell good Robin this gold I will borrow,
Meet you at stepney pay you all to morrow,

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: A dew Gloster,

SP.SPEAKER: Gl.
SP.P: Farwell, be short; you gone, I hope to haue a little sport

SP.SPEAKER: Ric:
SP.P: Take heed mad Cuz. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Tut tell not me of heed,
He that's too wray neuer hath good speed.
SP.STAGE: Hollowing within, Enter Lanc. with a broken staffe in his hand.
SP.L: Whose this old Lancaster my honoured frend?

SP.SPEAKER: Lan.
SP.L: These knaues haue seru'd me well, left me alone,
I haue hunted fairely, lost my purse, my chaine,
My Iewels, and bin bangd by a bold knaue,
Clad in a Hermits gowne like an olde man,
O what a world is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Its ill my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lan.
SP.L: Hee's come againe, O knaue tis the worse for thee,
Keepe from me, be content with that thou hast,
And see thou flie this heath, for if I take thee,
Ile make thee to all theeues aspectacle,
Had my staffe held, thou hadst not scaped me so,
But come not neare me, follow not thou art best,
Holla, Earle Leyster, holla Huntsman hoe?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Vppon my life, old Lancaster a Hunting,
Hath met my fellow Hermit, could I meet him,
Ide play rob theefe, at least part stakes with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.L: Zounds he is yonder alone,
Skinke now reuenge thy selfe on yonder slaue.
Znayles still preuented? this same Redcap rogue
Runs like hob-goblin vp and downe the heath.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.L: Wh wh wh whope He Hermit, ye ha ha ma ma made
Re Redcap run a fine co co compasse, ha haue you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: I made thee run?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Younders my euill Angell, were redcap gone, Gloster would coniure him.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Ie Ie Iesus bl blesse me, whop to to two Hermits? Ile ca ca caperclaw to to tone of yee, for mo mo mocking me, and I d d doo not ha ha hang me: wh wh which is the fa fa false k k k knaue? for I am s s sure the olde He He Hermit wo would neuer mo mocke an honest man.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: he is the counterfet he mockt thee fellow.
I did not see thee in my life before,
He weares my garments, and has coussoned me,

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.L: Haue you co co cousoned the he Hermit and m made
Redcap run to no pu pu purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: No he's counterfet I will tell no lyes,
As sure as Skinke deceiu'd thee of thy clothes,
Sent thee to Kent, gaue thee thy fare by water,
So sure hee's false, and I the perfet Hermit,

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: This villaine is a coniurer I doubt,
Were he the deuill yet I would not budge,

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Si si sirra, you are the co countefeite, O this is the tr tr true He Hermit, sta sta stand still g good man at that, ile bu bumbast you yfaith, ile make you g giue the olde m m man his gowne.
SP.STAGE: Offers to strike, Gloster trippes vp his heeles, shifts Skinke into his place.
SP.P: G g gods lid are ye go good at that? ile cu cudgell yee f f for this tr tr tricke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: It was not I twas he that cast thee downe,

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: You li li li lye you ra ra rascall you, I le left ye st stan∣ding he heare.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: Zounds hold you stammerer, or Ile cut your stumps.

SP.SPEAKER: Gl.
SP.P: He's for me he's weapon'd, I like that.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: O heer's a ro ro rogue in ca ca carnat, help, mu murder murder.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Lancaster & Huntsmen at one doore, Leyster & Huntsmen at another.

SP.SPEAKER: Lan.
SP.P: Lay holde vpon that theeuish counterfeit,

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.P: Why heares another Hermit Lancaster:

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: I am the Hermit sir, that wretched man
Doth many a robberie in my disguise:

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Its he that robs, he slaunders me, he lies.

SP.SPEAKER: Lan.
SP.P: Which set on thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Th this f f fellow has a s s sword and a buckler.

SP.SPEAKER: Lan.
SP.L: Search him; this is the theefe, o heares my purse,
My chaine, my Iewels: oh thou wicked wretch,
How darst thou vnder show of holines,
Commit such actions of impietie?
Bind him, Ile haue him made a publicke scorne.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: Lay holde vpon that other hermit.
He is a counterfeit as well as I,
He stole those clothes from me, for I am Skinke,
Search him, I know him not, he is some slaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Thou lyest base varlet.

SP.SPEAKER: Re.
SP.P: O g God he has a sword too, S Skink are you ca catcht?

SP.SPEAKER: Lan.
SP.P: Villaine thou shalt with me vnto the Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.P: And this with me, this is the traytor Gloster.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Thou lyest proud Leyster I am no traytor.

SP.SPEAKER: Re.
SP.P: G gloster? O b braue, now m my father sh shal be f free

SP.SPEAKER: Lan.
SP.P: Earle Gloster I am sorry thou art taken.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: I am not taken yet, nor will I yeild
To any heare but noble Lancaster,
Let Skinke be Leysters prisoner Ile be thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ley,
SP.P: Thou shalt be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Gl.
SP.L: First through a crimson sluce, Ile send thy hated soule to those blacke fiendes
That long haue houered gaping for their parte,
When tyrant life should leaue thy traytor heart.
Come Lancaster keep Skinke ile goe with thee,
Let loose the mad knaue, for I prayse his shifts,
He shall not starte away, ile be his guide,
And with proude looks outface young Henries pride.

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.P: Looke to them Lancaster vpon thy life.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P:
Well ile r r run and get a p pardon of the K K KKing, Gl Gloster and Skinke ta ta taken? O b b braue, r r r run re
Re Red ca cap a and ca ca cary the first n n newes to co co court.

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.P: Lancaster ile helpe to guarde them to the Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Lan.
SP.P: Doe as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Leyster doe not come neare me, for if thou doe, thou shalt buy it dearely.

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.P: Ile haue thy hand for this.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Not for thy heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: Braue Earle, had Skinke knowne thou hadst been the Noble Gloster (whose mad trickes haue made mee loue thee) I would haue dy'd Blacke heath red with the bloud of millions, ere we would haue been taken; but what reme∣dy, we are fast & must answere it like Gentlemen, like Soul∣diers, like resolutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Gl.
SP.L: I ye are a gallant, come olde Lancaster,
For thy sake will I goe; or else by heauen
Ide send some dozen of these slaues to hel. Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Prince Richard, Robert Hoode & Lady Faukenbridge.

SP.SPEAKER: La,
SP.L: Your trauaile and your comfortable newes,
This Ring, the certaine signe you met with him,
Bindes me in duetyous loue vnto your grace:
But on my knees I fall, and humbly craue,
Importune that no more, you nere can haue.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Nay then ye wrong me Lady Faukenbridge,
Did you not ioyne your faire white hand?
Swore that ye would forsweare your husbands bed,
If I could but finde out Gloster?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I sweare so?

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: By heauen

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Take heed, its a high oath my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: What meanst thou Huntington?

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: To saue your soule, I doe not loue to haue my friends forsworne,
She neuer promist that you vrge her with.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: Goe to, prouoke me not.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: I tell you true, twas I in her attyre that promist you,
She was gone vnto the wizard at Blacke heath,
And there had suters more then a good many.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: Was I deluded then?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: No not deluded, but hindred from desire vnchast and rude:
O let me wooe yee with the tongue of ruth,
Dewing your Princely hand with pitties teares,
That you would leaue this most vnlawful sute,
If ere we liue till Faukenbridge be dead,
(As God defend his death I should desire)
Then if your highnes daine so base a match,
And holy lawes admit a mariage,
Considering our affinity in bloud,
I will become your Handmayde not your harlot.
That shame shall neuer dwell vpon my brow.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: I faith my Lord she's honorably resolu'd,
For shame no more, importune her no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Ri.
SP.L: Marian I see thy vertue, and commend it,
I know my error seeking thy dishonor,
But the respectlesse, reasonles commaund
Of my inflamed loue, bids me still try,
And trample vnder foote all pietye.
Yet for I will not seeme too impyous,
Too inconsiderate of thy seeming griefe,
Vouchsafe to be my Mistris: vse me kindely,
And I protest ile striue with all my power,
That lust himselfe may in his heate deuour.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: You are my seruant then.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: Thankes sacred Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.P: What am I?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: You are my fellow Robert.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Faukenbridge in his hose and dublet.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: What Prince Richard? noble Huntington?
Welcome, yfaith welcome, by the morrow Masse
You are come as fitly as my heart can wish:
Prince Iohn this night will be a Reueller,
He hath inuited me and Marian.
Gods mary mother goe along with vs,
Its but hard by, close by, at our towne Tauerne.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: Your Tauerne?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: O I I I tis his owne made match,
Ile make you laugh, ile make you laugh yfaith;
Come, come, he's ready, O come, come away.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: But wher's the Princesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.L: He's ready too, Block Bl. my man, must be her waiting man,
Nay wil ye goe? for gods sake let vs goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ri.
SP.P: Is the iest so? nay then let vs away.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: O twill allay his heate, make dead his fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Ye bob'd me first, ye first gaue me my hyre,
But come a gods name, Prince Iohn stayes for vs. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: This is the word, euer at spend-thriftes feastes,
They are guld themselues, and scoft at by their guests. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.L: Buffild and scoft, Skinke, Gloster, women, fooles, and boyes abuse me?
Ile be reueng'd,

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Reueng'd, and why good childe?
Olde Faukenbridge hath had a worser basting.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.L: I, they haue banded from chase to chase;
I haue been their tennis ball, since I did coort,

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Come Iohn, take hand with vertuous Isabell,
And lets vnto the Court like louing friends,
Our Kingly brothers birth daies feastiuall,
Is foorthwith to be kept, thether we'l hye,
And grace with pompe that great solemnity.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: Whether ye wil, I care not where I goe:
If griefe wil grace it, ile adorne the shew.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.P: Come Madam, we must thither we are bound.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I am loath to see the Court, Gloster being from thence,
Or kneele to him that gaue vs this offence.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.P: Body of me peace woman. I prethee peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Go go god ye, go god s speed ye,

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.P: Whether run you sir knaue?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: R r run ye sir knaue? why I r run to my La Lady Fa Fau∣kenbridge, to te te tell her Sk Skinke and Gl Gloster is t ta∣ken, and are gg one to the CC Court with L Lord Leyster, and L Lord la la Lancaster.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Is Gloster taken? thether will I flye
Vpon wraths wings, not quiet til he dye. Exit with Princesse

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: Is Gloster taken?

SP.SPEAKER: Red:
SP.P: I he is ta taken I wa warrant ye with a wi witnes,

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Then will I to Court, & eyther set him free, or dye the death,
Follow me Faukenbridge, feare not faire Madam:
You said you had the Porter in your house,
Some of your seruants bring him, on my life
One hayre shal not be taken from his head,
Nor he, nor you, nor Gloster iniured.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.P: Come Mall, and Richard say the word nere feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: Madam, we haue twenty thousand at our call,
The most, young Henry dares, is but to braule.

SP.SPEAKER: La:
SP.P: Pray God it prooue so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric:
SP.P: Follow Huntington: sir Rich. doe not faile to send the Porter.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa:
SP.P: Blocke, bring the Porter of the Fleete to Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Bl.
SP.P: I wil sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Red:
SP.P: The p p Porter of the fl fl Fleete to Court? what p p porter of the fl fl Fleete?

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: What Redcap, run redcap, wilt thou see thy father?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: My fa father? I that I w wold s see my f father, & there be a p porter in your ho house, its my f far.

SP.SPEAKER: Bl.
SP.P: Follow me Redcap then. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: And you were two to twenty b Blockes, ide f f follow ye s so I would, and r run to the co co court too, and k kneele before the k k King f f for his pa pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Block within.
SP.P: Come away Redcap, run Redcap.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: I I I r r run as f f fast as I I ca ca can run I wa warrant yee.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter a Sinet, first two Herraldos, after them Leyster with a Scepter, Lancaster with a Crowne Imperiall on a cushion: After them Henry the elder bareheaded, bearing a swoord and a Globe: after him young Henry Crowned: Elinor the mother Queene Crowned: young Queene Crowned. Henry the elder places his Sonne, the two Queenes on eyther hand, himselfe at his feete, Leyster and Lancaster below him.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Herrald, fetch Lancaster and Leyster Coronets,
Suffer no Marquesse, Earle, nor Countesse enter,
Except their temples circled are in golde,
SP.STAGE: He deliuers Coronets to Leyster and Lancaster.
SP.L: Shew them our vize-roys: by our will controld
As at a cornation, euery Peere
Appeares in all his pompe, so at this feast
Held for our birth-right, let them be adorn'd.
Let Gloster be brought in, crown'd like an Earle, Exit
This day we'll haue no parley of his death,
But talke of Iouisanes and gleefull mirth.
Let Skinke come in, giue him a Barons seat,
High is his spirrit, his deserts are greate.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: You wrong the honour of Nobilitie,
To place a robber in a Barons stead,

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.P: Its well ye tearme him not a murtherer.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: Had I mistearmed him?

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: I that had you Henry.
He did a peece of Iustice at my Bidding.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: Who made you a Iustice?

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: I that had the power.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: You had none then.

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.P: Yes he was crownd before.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Why does not Gloster weare a Coronet?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Because his Soueraigne doth not weare a Crowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: By heauen put on thy Coronet, or that heauen
Which now with a clear, lends vs this light,
Shall not be courtain'd with the vaile of night,
Eare on thy head I clap a burning Crowne,
Of red hot Yron that shall seare thy braines.

SP.SPEAKER: Ri.
SP.P: Good Gloster Crowne thee with thy Coronet.

SP.SPEAKER: Lan.
SP.P: Doo gentle Earle.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Swounds doo, would I had one.

SP.SPEAKER: Qu.
SP.P: Doo not I prethee keepe thy proud heart still.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Ile weare it but to crosse thy froward will.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Sit downe and take thy place.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Its the low earth.
To her I must, from her I had my breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: We are pleas'd thou shalt sit there, Skinke take thy place among my nobles.

STAGE.HI: Enter Iohn and Jsabell with Coronets.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: Thankes to King Henries grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Iohn Earle of Morton and of Notingham,
With Isabell his Countesse, bow themselues
Before their brother Henries Royall Throane.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Assend your seats liue in our daily loue.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Richard, and Robert with Coronts.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Richard the Prince of England, with his Ward
The noble Robert Hood, Earle Huntington,
Present their seruice to your Maiestie.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Y'are welcome too, though little be your loue.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Faukenbridge with his Lady, she a Coronet

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.L: Olde Richard Faukenbridge, Knight of the crosse,
Lord of the Cinque ports, with his noble wife
Dame Marrian Countesse of west Hereford,
Offer their duties at this Royall meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Sit downe, thou art a newter, she a foe,
Thy loue we doubt her hart too well we know.
What sutors are without, let them come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: And haue no Iustice where contempt is King.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Mad man I giue no eare to thy loose words.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: O sir y'are welcome, you haue your old seat.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Though thou sit hier yet my heart's as great.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.P: Great heart wee'll make you lesser by the head.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Ill comes not euer to the threatned.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: What are you two?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: M ma mary and't please you I am re re Redcap.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: And what's your mate?

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: A poore Porter sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.P: The Porter of the fleet that was condemned.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.L: No truely sir I was Porter last, when I left
The doore open at the Tauerne.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: O ist you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.P: And what would you two haue?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: I co co come to re re re qui quier the young K K King of his go goo goodnes, since Glo Gloster is t taken, that he wo wo would let my fa fa father haue his pa pa pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Sirra your father has his pardon sign'd,
Go to the office it shall be deliuered.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: And shall he be p p Porter a ga gaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: I that he shall, but let him be aduis'd
Heareafter, how lets out prisoners,

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: I wa warrant ye my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: What hast thou more to say?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Marry I wo would haue Skinke pu punisht for co co Cunnicatching me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ley,
SP.P: Is that your busines?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: I by my t t troth is it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Then get away.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Against Skinke (poore knaue)
Thou gets no right this day.

SP.SPEAKER: Blo.
SP.P: O but run backe Redcap for the Purseuant.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: O I Lord s sir, I haue another s sute for the p p Purse∣uant, that has l l lost his b b box, and his wa wa warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: What meanes the fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Why the pu pu Purseuant sir and the po po Porter.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: The box that I had from him, there it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: Mary a me, and I was chargd with it.
Had you it brother Gloster? Gods good mercy,

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: And what haue you to say?

SP.SPEAKER: Bl.
SP.P: Nothing sir but God blesse you, you are a goodly com∣pany, except sir William or my Lady wil command me any more seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: A way you prating knaue, hence varlet, hence. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.P: Put forth them fellowes there.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: A f fo fore I go goe I b b be s s seech you let Sk Skinke and gl Gloster be lo lo looked too, for they haue p p playd the k k knaues to to to b b bad.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Take hence that stuttering fellow, shut them forth.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Nay Ile ru ru run, faith you shall not n n need to b b b bid him ta ta take m me away, for re re Redcap will r ru run rarely. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: The sundrie misdemeanors late committed,
As theftes and shifts in other mens disguise,
We now must (knaue Skinke) freely tell thy faults.

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: Sweet King by these two terrors to myne enemies, that lend light to my bodies darknes: Cauilero Skinke being beleagerd with an hoste of leaden heeles, arm'd in ring Irish: cheated my hammerer of his Red cap and Coate; was surprised, brought to the fleet as a person suspected, past currant, till Gloster stript me from my counterfet, clad my backe in silke and my hart in sorrow, and so left me to the mercy of my mother witt: how Prince Iohn releast me, he knowes: howe I got Faukenbridges chaine, I know: but how he will get it againe, I know not.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Where is it sirra, tell me where it is?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: I got it from him, and I got Iohns sword,

SP.SPEAKER: Joh.
SP.P: I would twere to the hilts vp in thy harte.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: O be more charitable brother Iohn.

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.L: My Leidge, you need not by perticulars
Examine what the world knows too plaine,
If you will pardon Skinke, his life is sau'd,
If not, he is conuicted by the Law.
For Gloster: as you worthyly resoul'd,
First take his hand, and afterward his head.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Skinke thou hast life, our pardon and our loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: And your forgiuenesse for my robbery?

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Tut neuer trouble me with such a toy.
Thou hindrest me from hearing of my ioye.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Bring forth a blocke, wine, water and towell,
Kniues, and a Surgion to binde vp the vaines,
Of Glosters arme: when his right hand is off,
His hand that strooke Skinke at the Parlament:

SP.SPEAKER: Sk.
SP.P: I shall beare his blowes to my graue my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Sonne Henry see thy fathers palzie hands,
Ioyn'd like two supplyants, pressing to thy throwne?
Looke how the furrowes of his aged cheeke,
Fild with the reuolets of wet eyde mone,
Begs mercy for Earle Gloster? weigh his gilt,
Why for a slaue, should Royall blood be spilt?

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: You wrong myne honour: Skink may be reueng'd,

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Father I doe commend your humble course.
But quite dislike the proiect of your sute,
Good words in an ill cause makes the fact worse,
Of blood or Basenes, Iustice will dispute,
The greater man the greater his transgression,
Where strength wrongs weaknes, it is meare oppression,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: O but King Henry heare a sister speake,
Gloster was wrong'd, his lands were giuen away,
They are not Iustly said. Iust lawes to break,
That keep their owne right, with what power they may,
Thinke then thy Royall selfe began the wrong,
In giuing Skinke what did to him belong.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: Heare me Sonne Henry, while thou art a King,
Giue, take, pryson, thy subiects are thy slaues,
Life, need, thrones proud hearts in dungions fling.
Grace men to day, to morrowe giue them graues.
A King must be like Fortune; euer turning,
The world his football, all her glory spurning.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Still your olde counsaile Beldam pollicie,
You'r a fit Tutresse in a Monarchy.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.L: Mother you are vniust, sauage, too cruell,
Vnlike a woman: gentlenes guides their sexe,
But you to furyes fire ad more fewell,
The vexed spirit, will you delight to vex?
O God when I consaite what you haue done,
I am a sham'd to be estem'd your sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: Base Richard I disdaine to call thee brother,
Takest thou a traytors part in our disgrace?
For Gloster, wilt thou wrong our sacred mother?
I scorne thee and defie thee to thy face.
O that we were in field, then shouldst thou trie,

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: How fast Earle Iohn would from Prince Richard flye
Thou meet a Lyon in feeld? poore mouse,
All thy Carreers are in a Brothell house.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.P: Zounds boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: Now man:

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.P: Richard you wrong Prince Iohn.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: Leyster tweare Good you proou'd his Champion.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: Hasten the execution Royall Lord,
Let deeds make answer for their worthlesse wordes.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: I know if I respected hand or head,
I am encompassed with a world of frends,
And could from fury bee deliuered.
But then my freedom hazards many liues.
Henry performe the vtmost of thy hate,
Let thy hard harted mother haue her wil,
Giue Franticke Iohn no longer cause to prate,
I am prepared for the worst of ill,
You see my knees kisse the could pauements face,
They are not bent to Henry nor his frends,
But to all you whose bloud fled to your hearts,
Shewes your true sorrowe in your ashye cheekes:
To you I bend my knees, you I intreat,
To smile on Glosters Resolution.
Who euer loues me will not shed a teare,
Nor breath a sigh, nor show a cloudy frowne,
Looke Henry, heares my hand, I lay it downe,
And sweare as I haue Knighthood heer't shall lye,
Till thou haue vsed all thy tyranny.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Has no man heart to speake?

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Let all that loue me keepe silence, or by heauen Ile hate them dying.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.P: Harry off with his hand, then with his head.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.L: By the red rood I cannot chuse but weepe.
Come loue or hate my teares I cannot keepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.P: When comes this lingring executioner?

SP.SPEAKER: Joh.
SP.P: An executioner: an executioner:

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Call none till we haue drunke: father fill wine,
To day your Office is to beare our cupp.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: Ile fill it Henry. K. kneele downe.

SP.SPEAKER: He.
SP.P: Dick you are too meane, so bow vnto your soueraigne,

SP.SPEAKER: Gl.
SP.L: Kneele to his childe? O hell! O tortor! (Gloster learne:
Who would loue life, to see this huge dishonor?

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Saturne kneel'd to his Sonne the God was faine
To call young Ioue his ages Soveraigne.
Take now your seate againe and weare your Crowne;
Now shineth Henry like the Middayes Sonne,
Through his Horizon, darting all his beames,
Blinding with his bright splendor euery eye,
That stares against his face of Maiesty.
The Commets, whose malicious gleames
Threatned the ruyne of our Royalty,
Stands at our mercy, yet our wrath denyes
All fauour, but extreame extreamityes.
Gloster, haue to thy sorrow chafe thy arme
That I may see thy bloud (I long'd for oft)
Gush from thy vaines, and staine this Pallace roofe.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Twould exceed gilding.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.P: I as golde doth Oaker.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Its wel ye count my bloud so precious.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Leyster reach Gloster wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ley.
SP.P: I reach it him?

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Proude Earle ile spurne thee, quickely go & beare it

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Ile count it poyson if his hand come neere it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Giue it him Leyster vpon our displeasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: Thus Gloster takes it, thus againe he flings it,
In scorne of him that sent it, and of him that brought it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.P: O braue spirit▪

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Brauely resolu'd brother, I honour thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.L: Harke how his sister ioyes in his abuse?
Wilt thou indure it Hall?

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Peace good Marian.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Auoyde there euery vnder Officer.
Leaue but vs, our Pieres and Ladyes heere.
Richard you loue Earle Gloster looke about
If you can spye one in this company,
That hath not done as great a sinne as Gloster;
Chuse him, let him be the executioner.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Thou hast done worse then, like rebellie us head,
Hast arm'd ten thousand hands against his life
That lou'd thee so, as thou wert made a King,
Being his childe, now he's thy vnderling.
I haue done worse: thrise I drew my swoord,
In three set battles for thy false defence.
Iohn hath done worse, he still hath tooke thy part,
All of vs three haue smitte our fathers heart;
Which made proude Leyster bolde to strike his face,
To his eternall shame, and our disgrace.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Silence, I see thou leanst to finde none fit.
I am sure, nor Lancaster nor Huntington,
Nor Faukenbridge, will lay a hand on him.
Mother, wife, brother, lets descend the Throane
Where Henry is the Monarch of the West,
Hath set amongst his Princes dignified.
Father take you the place, see Iustice.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: Its iniust Iustice I must tell thee Sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Mother holde you the Bason, you the Towell,
I know your French hearts thirst for English bloud;
Iohn, take the Mallet, I will holde the knife,
