And when I bid thee smite, strike for thy life:
Make a marke Surgion, Gloster now prepare thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: Tut, I am ready, to thy worst I dare thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Then haue I done my worst, thrise honoured Earle,
I doe imbrace thee in affections armes.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.P: What meanes thou Henry? O what meanes my Son?

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: I meane no longer to be lullaby'd,
In your seditious armes.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen. wife.
SP.P: Mordieu Henry.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen:
SP.L: Mordieu nor deuill, little tit of Fraunce,
I know your hart leapes, at our hearts mischaunce,

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Swounds Henry thou art mad:

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: I haue bin mad; what stampst thou Iohn? knowst thou not who I am?
Come stamp the deuill out, suckt from thy Dam.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.P: Ile cursse thee Henry.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Your best be quiet, least where we finde you, to the Tower we beare you,
For being abroad, England hath cause to feare yee.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: I am strucke dombe with wonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.P: I amaz'd, imagine that I see a vizion.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Gloster, I giue thee first this Skinke, this slaue,
Its in thy power, his life to spill or saue,

SP.SPEAKER: Skin.
SP.P: He's a noble gentleman, I doe not doubt his vsage.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Stand not thus wondring, Princes kneele all downe,
And cast your Coronets before his Crowne.
Downe stubborne Queene, kneele to your wronged King,
Downe Mammet; Leyster ile cut of thy legs,
If thou delay thy duety: when proude Iohn?

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Nay if all kneele, of force I must be one.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Now by my holydom a vertuous deed.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Father you see your most rebellious sonne,
Stricken with horror of his horred guilt,
Requesting sentence fitting his desart,
O treade vpon his head, that trode your heart.
I doe deliuer vp all dignity,
Crowne, Scepter, swoord vnto your Maiesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: My heart surfets with ioy in hearing this.
And deare Sonne ile blesse thee with a kisse.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: I will not rise, I will not leaue this ground,
Till all these voyces ioyned in one sound:
Cry, God saue Henry second of that name,
Let his friends liue, his foes see death with shame.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: God saue Henry second of that name,
Let his friends liue, his foes see death with shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.P: Amen, Amen, Amen.

SP.SPEAKER: Joh.
SP.L: Harke mother harke?
My brother is already turned Clarke.

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.P: He is a recreant, I am mad with rage.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Be angry at your enuy gracious mother,
Learne patience and true humility
Of your worst tuter'd Sonne, for I am he.
Send hence that Frenchwoman, giue her her dowry,
Let her not speake, to trouble my milde soule,
Which of this world hath taken her last leaue:
And by her power, will my proude flesh controule.
Off with these silkes, my garments shall be gray,
My shirt hard hayre, my bed the ashey dust,
My pillow but a lumpe of hardned clay:
For clay I am, and vnto clay I must,
O I beseech ye let me goe alone,
To liue, where my loose life I may bemone.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: Sonne?

SP.SPEAKER: Quee.
SP.P: Sonne?

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: Brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Let none call me their Sonne, I am no mans brother,
My kindred is in heauen, I know no other,
Farewell, farewell, the world is yours, pray take it,
Ile leaue vexation, and with ioy forsake it. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Wondrous conuersion.

SP.SPEAKER: Fau.
SP.P: Admirable good: now by my holydam Mall passing good.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: H'ath sir'd my soule I will to Palestine,
And pay my vowes before the Sepulcher,
Among the multitude of misbeliefe.
Ile shew my selfe the Souldier of Christ,
Spend bloud, sweat teares, for satisfaction
Of many many sinnes which I lament:
And neuer thinke to haue them pardoned,
Till I haue part of Sirria conquered.

SP.SPEAKER: Glo.
SP.L: He makes me wonder, and inflames my spirits,
With an exceeding zeale to Portingale,
Which Kingdome the vnchristned Sarisons,
The blacke fac'd Affricans, and tawny Moores,
Haue got vniustly in possession:
Whence I will fire them with the help of heauen.

SP.SPEAKER: Ski.
SP.L: Skinke will scotrch them braue Gloster
Make Carbonadoes of their Bacon fletches;
Deserue to be counted valiant by his valour,
And Ryuo will he cry, and Castile too,
And wonders in the land of Ciuile doo.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: O that I were a man to see these fights,
To spend my bloud amongst these worthy Knights.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.L: Mary aye me, were I a boy againe,
Ide either to Ierusalem or Spaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SP.L: Faith Ile keepe England, mother you and I
Will liue, for all this fight and foolery.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Peace to vs all, let's all for peace giue prayse,
Vnlookt for peace, vnlookt for happy dayes.
Loue Henries birth day, he hath bin new borne,
I am new crowned, new settled in my seate.
Lets' all to the Chappell, there giue thankes and praise,
Beseeching grace from Heauens eternal Throne,
That England neuer know more Prince then one. Exeunt
